div.head: The Autobiography of Dr. Edward A. Rumely: The Formative Years, 1882-1900

byline.hi: Edited by Philip Morehouse McGarr∗ Contributed by Mrs. Fanny Scott Rumely

div.p: The autobiography of Edward A. Rumely, an American industrialist, educator, and editor of the first half of the twentieth century, is a remarkable document and an exemplar of its genre. A number of circumstances prompted Rumely to undertake an accounting of his life. He was, first of all, an accomplished newspaper editor and publisher and doubtless felt he could tap this reservoir of experience. Secondly, he received enthusiastic encouragement from his immediate family, particularly his devoted wife of over forty years, Mrs. Fanny Scott Rumely,1 and several close friends. The example of Mrs. Rumely's father, Emmet Hoyt Scott, who at the time of his death in 1924 had completed 276 pages of his autobiography, perhaps provided another impetus.2 Finally, the existence and availability of Rumely's own papers made possible and practical the writing of a memoir.

According to Mrs. Rumely her husband began his autobiography by dictating into a wire recorder (this was before the days of tape recorders) one evening a week with his wife and daughter sitting by. They would ask leading questions to bring out details and elucidate various points as needed. The wire recordings were then typed and given to Samuel Thurston Williamson, a family friend of many years and a staff writer for the New York Times and former editor of Newsweek. Williamson worked over the transcripts and put them into

Edward A. Rumely was born at La Porte, Indiana, on February 28, 1882, the second son of Joseph and Margaret Rumely and the second grandchild of Meinrad and Theresa Rumely. The first child, named Joseph, died before Edward was born; therefore, the latter was considered by his family as the first son. This primogenital position proved auspicious. Edward's Rumely grandparents bestowed special favors on him, and he became a frequent visitor at their home. Grandmother Rumely welcomed the inquisitive boy into her kitchen and acquainted him with the mysteries of cooking. Undoubtedly his grandmother's warmth and her encouragement of his youthful curiosity affected him. Rumely, in fact, credits this early experience as a factor in his lifelong interest in vitamins and nutrition. The favoritism was extended by Grandfather Rumely in other ways. He allowed Edward to tinker in his machine shop; and when the boy informed him that he had read all the books in the public library, his grandfather replied, "Whatever books you promise to read I will pay for." He kept his word in spite of the enormous number of books Edward ordered, some of which were on such controversial subjects as the single tax and evolution. On the maternal side Grandmother Ludwina Schweitzer Zimmerman and her youngest son, Frank, were exceptionally kind to young Eddie, as he was affectionately called.

Rumely implies that his family provided a wholesome and positive atmosphere, conducive to learning. He, in turn, developed a progressive spirit, respect for the broader aspects of religion, a belief in a way of life that emphasizes service to others, a genuine desire for knowledge, self-reliance based on intellectual accomplishment, an appreciation of the pursuit of formal education, satisfaction derived from industrious labor, a creative urge to combine esthetic and utilitarian concepts, a sensitivity to the south German heritage of his forebears, the courage to follow his ideas even when they were unpopular with the crowd, and an appreciation of the value of American democracy and the free enterprise system.

Rumely's stay at Notre Dame was brief and turbulent. He was receptive to the free flowing ideas of the close of the nineteenth century, and his intellectual curiosity drew him into a whirlpool of controversy. The writings of Charles Darwin and Herbert Spencer, Henry George's Progress and Poverty, and Louis F. Post's The Public, a single tax newspaper, ignited the flame of activism in him. The majority of Notre Dame's faculty, however, had not accepted the revolutionary ideas of environmental determinism and evolution. Consequently, Rumely was labeled a student radical for his participation in the formulation of the Henry George Debating Society and incurred the wrath of conservative faculty members and administrators. While at Notre Dame Rumely's questioning of ecclesiastical dicta put to rest any lingering thoughts he may have had of a life devoted to his church. His English professor, Austin O'Malley, apparently thought he should reject his grandmother's wish that he become a priest because his "obstinate nature and independent viewpoint would get him into difficulty" with ecclesiastical discipline. His professor's evaluation proved correct. Faculty rivalry, administrative inflexibility, and Rumely's reputation as a student radical, coupled with his refusal to abide by what he considered an unfair faculty decision, caused him to leave Notre Dame abruptly but voluntarily.4 He accepted the advice of Louis F. Post to continue his education in England and eventually entered Ruskin Hall in the city of Oxford, where he could earn his board and room by participating in household chores and attend classes at the same time.5 Rumely's decision to leave the United States was reinformed by his school friend, Alexander Lattimore, who agreed to accompany him to England.

Rumely took the opportunity while he was in Europe to travel and to attend three universities. He spent one year at Ruskin Hall in Oxford; a second year at Heidelberg University, Heidelberg, Germany; and the remaining four and one half years at Freiburg University, Freiburg, Baden, Germany, where he received the M.D. degree magna cum laude and completed the requirements for a degree in economics in 1906.

Joseph Rumely, Edward's father, attended Notre Dame as a "minum" from 1867-1872. The minum program which was high school level college preparatory work, operated at the university until the 1920s. The institution was not connected in any way with Oxford University and was run on a cooperative basis with everyone-faculty and students-sharing in the work. It is today called Ruskin College.

div.p: After his return to La Porte in 1906 Rumely became involved in building the Interlaken School for Boys and in working in the family agricultural implement business, the M. Rumely Company. Both of these endeavors proved rewarding. Rumely was founder and owner of Interlaken, a college preparatory boarding school for boys who were also taught shop and farm work. His endeavors with the M. Rumely Company provided ample capital to expand Interlaken. He was responsible for the development of the Rumely Oil Pull Farm Tractor and helped raise company sales from $1,000,000 a year to $38,000,000 by 1913. He resigned at age thirty-two as an officer of the firm and moved his family to New York City where he resided until his retirement and return to La Porte in 1959.

In 1915 Rumely became editor-in-chief and publisher of one of New York's leading daily newspapers, the New York Evening Mail, which he and a number of colleagues had purchased. On friendly terms with Theodore Roosevelt, Rumely permitted the ex-President to continue to use the Evening Mail, as his mouthpiece.6 For a short time two distinguished critics of the American scene wrote articles for the Rumely newspaper: Samuel S. McClure, from 1915 to 1918, and H. L. Mencken, from 1917 to 1918.

In the 1920s Rumely pursued his interests and civic minded activities. He became a pioneer in the introduction of vitamins and vitamin containing foods to the retail market. From 1923 to 1928 he was executive director of the Vitamin Foods, Inc., of Westfield, Massachusetts. He organized the Super Diesel Company in 1925, and from 1926 to 1930 he helped loan farmers $30,000,000 through the Agricultural Bond and Credit Company which he organized.

Remaining in New York from 1932 until his retirement in 1959, Rumely focused his attention upon national political questions. To his mind Aristotle's golden .mean of "nothing in excess" had under President Franklin Delano Roosevelt's New Deal taken on the appearance of "everything in excess." The pot pourri of government agencies (AAA, NRA, SEC, NLRB, NIRA, RFC, PWA, CWA, CCC, etc.)7 became for him an unpalatable alphabet soup. To alert the American people to what he considered excessive governmental power he served during the New Deal as executive secretary to both the Committee for the Nation and the National Committee to Uphold Constitutional
6 Theodore Roosevelt described Rumely as "one of the unhyphenated Americans of German descent who is an American through and through," and one who "has been particularly useful to me in connection with matters looking to a better handling of America's industrial and social life." Theodore Roosevelt to Charles Evans Hughes, September 18, 1916, Rumely Papers.
7 Agricultural Adjustment Administration, National Recovery Administration, Securities Exchange Administration, National Labor Relations Board, National Industrial Recovery Act, Reconstruction Finance Corporation, Public Works Administration, Civil Works Administration, and Civilian Conservation Corps.
Government. Early in 1941 he helped establish the Committee for Constitutional Government and remained active with the committee throughout the remaining Roosevelt and Harry S. Truman administrations.

One of Rumely's last projects after returning to La Porte in 1959, after fifty years of public service in New York state, was the distribution of Alton Ochsner's Smoking and Health to the fifty state medical societies. It was a gesture characteristic of his whole career, at once civic minded, forward looking, and bold. Rumely continued to lend support to those organizations whose purpose and philosophy agreed with his interpretation of American democracy and the free enterprise system. He was active, cheerful, and outgoing until he died in November, 1964, at the age of eighty-two.

Rumely achieved success in many, varied fields. In agriculture, education, business, editing, politics, nutrition, his contributions to Indiana in particular and to the nation as a whole were myriad. Rumely's perceptive comments about his life and environment make his autobiography both interesting and informative. The manuscript recreates the personality, accomplishments, philosophy, and principles of an unusual and outstanding citizen. Further, it provides a much needed glimpse of the history of northern Indiana and contributes to a better understanding of the cultural and social world of the first half of the twentieth century.

The first four completed chapters of the Rumely autobiography are reproduced below. "The Formative Years, 1882-1900" includes the author's account of the events and activities of his early life and his recollection of pioneer days in La Porte, Indiana. Rumely also notes his forebears' origins and reflects upon, among other things, the hazardous political climate in Germany after the abortive democratic revolution of 1848; the oppression of southern Germans by the Prussians; the immigration of his grandparents, the Rumelys, Zimmermans, Schweitzers, and Fierstosses, from their homes in the Black Forest and Alsace-Lorraine; the selection of La Porte as the ideal location for their new home; and the successful establishment of an agricultural implement business by Grandfather Meinrad Rumely.8 Two additional installments of the Rumely autobiography are tentatively scheduled for future issues of the Indiana Magazine of History.

div.p: When French explorers reached the end of Lake Michigan and its sand dunes in the late 1660's, they found a few miles inland a chain of small lakes and ponds which teemed with plump fish and clouds of water birds. Immediately to the South stretched rolling prairie lands. It was a pleasing place, this oak-lined gateway to the prairies, so the French named it "LaPorte," then pushed on to the gently flowing Kankakee and down it to the Mississippi.

Settlers did not come until a century later and after the Revolution. First were New Englanders who moved out to this Indiana section of the Northwest Territory either direct from their Yankee salt-box houses, or after stopping over a generation or two in New York State. Down the Ohio and up from the South came a few soft-spoken Virginians. The newcomers fancied the fertile ground between the lakes. After trying to conjure up a suitable name, they eventually decided they could not do better than the French, and so the place became and still is, La Porte.2

Here I was born. Here no one could ever have wished for a happier, more active, more character-forming boyhood. Here I returned after tasting university life abroad. Here I met and wed my bride. Here we had our two first-born and here I had my first successes and setbacks. No matter where I am, where I have been, my roots are in this pleasant, homelike northern Indiana city close by the Lake Michigan dune country.

They are good, sturdy roots. My people were of earthy German and Alsatian stock from the Black Forest and Upper Rhine. By instalments,
1 The version of the Rumely autobiography which appears below is that prepared by Samuel Williamson from the typescript of the wire recordings provided by Edward A. Rumely. The "Williamson" manuscript was typed, triple spaced, in pica type. The present editor worked with a carbon copy of this version of the Rumely autobiography on which were a number of additions and/or deletions—some handwritten, some typed in elite type. Since it was impossible to ascertain exactly when—or by whom—the changes in the "Williamson" manuscript were made, the following practices have been used in preparing the autobiography for publication: words which were marked out in the original typescript have been printed with a line through them, typewritten words which were added appear in boldface type, handwritten words are reproduced in italics, words suggested by Mrs. Fanny Scott Rumely during the present editing process have been added in parentheses. Throughout the manuscript there were occasional handwritten words which were illegible, seemingly irrelevant, or written in shorthand. These have been omitted. Obvious typographical errors-such as bou for boy, water for waiter, closed for closet, and caree for career have been corrected. Otherwise, spelling, punctuation, and grammar have been retained exactly as in the original. Whenever possible first names of people mentioned have been added in brackets.

they came to this country around and after the Revolution of 1848 when the last German bid for freedom was stamped out. They were industrious, but hard work had not dulled their minds or their spirit. They were thrifty, but never at the expense of good things of life, including hearty good things of the table. They were devout Roman Catholics but forgave me when I finally chose not to enter the priesthood. They were closely-knit and with another mother-tongue, but they welcomed my young wife of another religion and of ancestry dating back to the Pilgrim fathers.

The family name was Rümele. People in this country spelled it with an "ely" as it was pronounced, so my grandfather began writing it that way too, and the name became "Rumely." Meinrad Rumely, my grandfather, founded our family implement business in LaPorte and more than any other was responsible for bringing machine was a pioneer in building the modern threshing machine and steam-engine (and was responsible for bringing machine) power to the farm. He came from Adelsberg, a Baden hilltop town with dark pine of the Black Forest behind it.3 When I visited the place years later, it had changed little since Grandfather's time. The houses were straw-thatched, floors were of hardened earth, and there were no chimneys. When I asked a farmer where the smoke from the stove went, he replied "Whithersoever it listeth." Just under the roof hung hams and bacon for curing in this wandering smoke. When visitors came, the host and his frau cut down a slab of ham which they sliced into big pieces to eat on homemade rye bread, the rye being ground by the village millstone.

Through the years, many men and women have influenced my life and thought, but no one molded me more in the fundamentals than Grandfather Rumely, who took me in hand when I was very young and talked with me like an equal. He was a millwright in the old country, going from one place to another to build mills. One of his jobs took him across the Rhine to an Alsatian village not far from Strasbourg. There he built a mill for a landowner named Fierstoss, whose twelve-year-old daughter Theresa had dark eyes and coal-black hair. A few years later, Fierstoss sold out and moved his family to America.

Shortly after, Grandfather left for America in a bigger hurry than the Fierstoss family. "I remember those times very well," an old woman told me years later when I visited Adelsberg Markelsheim in my student days. "Early one morning we were awakened by a great
3 Meinrad Rumely was born in Adelsburg, near Zell, Baden, Germany, February 9, 1823. Unless otherwise indicated information concerning Edward A. Rumely and his family comes from Mrs. Fanny Scott Rumely.
commotion in the village. There we saw a crowd of young men and farmers—a few had guns, some had flails and others had scythes. ‘Where are you going?’ they were asked. ‘We are marching to Freiberg’ they said ‘we are going to establish a Republic.’ "

These poorly-armed young peasants did not get very far. Thirty years before, [Prince von Clemens] Metternich set up a structure for Europe which continued princes and reactionary forces in power. It was this rule by princelings and little autocrats that the people of 1848 were rising against. The King of Prussia [William I] sent his troops to three or four of the smaller states, including Baden, and the incipient rebellions led by Carl Schurz and his associates were crushed. Germany's history since 1848 has been dominated by the fact that, unlike France and England, mid-century liberalism there was checked and thwarted. The statesmanship of [Otto von] Bismark, the early efficient leadership furnished social legislation, army, and application of science to business, consolidated the strength of autocracy in Germany so thoroughly that only the disasters of defeat and pressure from the outside have been able to break it.

"Ja! I remember Meinrad Rümele" an old fellow digging potatoes in an Adelsberg field told me. "The last I saw of him was when he came back after the fighting, gathered up his things and slipped away before the Prussians caught him." Ever afterward my grandfather disliked Prussians and North Germans. When a man in his shop did something stupidly wrong, the worst thing he could think of was to call him a "North German sable."

A few jumps ahead of his Prussian pursuers in 1848, Grandfather went over the hills to Switzerland, then to the French coast and landed in New York with one dollar in his pocket. He got a job on an Erie Canalboat which got him to Buffalo and then he went on foot to Canton, Ohio, and to the Fierstoss farm.4 He found the whole family in the fields, cutting wheat with scythes and tying it into bundles with ropes of straw. Working alongside the dark-eyed, black-haired and now grown-up Theresa, Grandfather told her he would come back when he had money enough to marry her and start a family.

It was some years before he had enough money to do this, but Theresa was waiting. Eventually he reached Chicago, again on foot, after passing through and noting a blacksmith's shop for sale in the little village of LaPorte. At Chicago he was commissioned to build a steam fire engine which had more than enough to do twenty years

The fire engine job cleared him $400—enough to buy the blacksmith's shop which had taken his eye in LaPorte.6 He soon left horseshoeing for others, for Grandfather was one of those men who take to tools and machinery as naturally as—and as unaccountably—ducks to water. He had no technical or scientific training; there was none little then. He knew nothing of the higher mathematics now so essential to the engineering profession. Mechanical devices were simpler in those days, and Grandfather had the ability—I don't know how he acquired it—of reasoning from basic simplicity, a quality which I found in men like Henry Ford and which is a prime one for the successful inventor. Meinrad Rumely could plan and execute a machine without working from a drawing. He knew how much iron, cast iron or steel should go into each part, and he knew instinctively how thick each piece should be to resist strain and perform the work expected of it.

Almost any tool or machine needed in those early days in LaPorte, Grandfather seemed able to build. Sugar at that time came from sorghum raised in the neighborhood. One of Grandfather's first jobs in his blacksmith shop was to make rollers for pressing out the juice from the sorghum cane. He built sugar mills and flour mills, also ice harvesting machinery and wheels for railroad cars.7

In the early 1850's he made a threshing machine which won him a gold medal at a Chicago fair. Its motive was horsepower—four horses driven in a circle around a drum-like contrivance which set the thresher in motion. The red-painted machine, about as long as a circus wagon, was really the foundation of the Rumely Company, for others wanted to buy one like it. From a hundred miles around and neighboring counties farmers came with their ox teams and lived at Grandmother's, sometimes a week or two, waiting for the threshers they had ordered. In the pioneer life of the West, the household arts of the peasant life in Europe were those of my grandparents. My grandmothers made candles, spun, preserved fruit, made butter, cheese, had their own gardens, grew herbs for medicine, and very little had to be bought at the store. And so, Rumely customers didn't mind waiting for their machines.

When I was a small boy I once asked Grandfather why he started making machine threshers. We were driving with his stallion and

"Run up into the top of the barn and bring me a flegel." "What's that?" I asked. I knew it was German for flail. He said "That's a long stick with another one like one of your baseball bats tied to it." When I found the flail and brought it down, he told me to whip the straw with it. I hit my knuckles and skinned them but Grandfather forced me to keep on, beating time by whistling. I got tired. The flail was heavy to swing, but "keep on, keep on," said Grandfather. Finally, when I was completely tuckered out, he said, "Now, if you had to do that all winter as farmers used to do, you'd think of making a machine to do it for you, wouldn't you?" Then he took me outside the barnyard and said, pointing to the great opening prairies, "If you saw all of this land and knew that it could be planted in wheat and yet at harvest time there were not men enough to gather and flail the grain, wouldn't you think of making a machine to do it for you?"

After the Civil War, when most of the Middle West had been tamed into farm land, Grandfather's business grew rapidly. He built a small two-story factory with a casting foundry in its rear, and in a ten-by-ten office partitioned off from the workshop, fat old Herman Houser, a great lover of his pipe and his beer, kept books and accounts in characteristically Teutonic handwriting.

The growing Rumely plant had sales agents in Indianapolis, St. Louis and Minneapolis, and the growing number of Rumely sons (there were four Joseph H, William N., Meinrad C., A. J.) were sent away for the formal schooling which their father never had. Joseph Rumely, my father, took a commercial course at Notre Dame. Uncle William Rumely studied steam engineering at Stevens Institute; A. J. went to Purdue [.] The sons became possibly more learned than their father, but without the greater benefit of he made up his lack of formal education by his simplicity of thought and driving common sense.

The next step in development of Grandfather's thresher was to replace horse power with steam. In the 1870's the Rumely shops turned out a portable steam engine which could be horse-drawn from one farmyard to another and linked to the thresher by means of a driving belt. Its fuel was wood, coal, or hot-burning straw from the threshing operation. Thus, for the first time, power from engines rather than from draft animals and humans was applied on the American farm.8

div.p: The logical sequel ten years later was a traction engine employing its own steam power to propel itself and draw threshing machine and water wagon to the next appointment at a straw stack. This road locomotive required a larger steam boiler and a friction clutch9 which would engage the gears gradually in the flywheel so that the contraption got under way without jerking and tossing the driver out of his post of responsibility iron seat. When other implement makers also came out with traction engines employing the friction clutch, a man who claimed to be its inventor haled all and sundry into court in a patent suit. The complainant was on the point of winning his suit when a customer of the Rumely Company read in a farm paper about the litigation and wrote, "I bought one of your engines a long time ago, and I rigged up to it a friction clutch and pulled my threshing rig all over my county years before this man who claims to be the inventor took out his patent."

The customer's affidavit broke the patent suit and freed all threshing machine makers from the threat of making heavy royalty payments. This litigation was akin to the Selden patent suit in the automobile industry, when Henry Ford, alone of all motor car manufacturers defied and broke a patent monopoly.10 Rarely have I ever seen such an ironic situation the day after the Selden patent decision. I was traveling to Detroit and visiting Mr. Ford in his compartment when one after another auto manufacturer who had been on the opposite side of the case came in to congratulate him and thank him for having freed their industry from paying tribute to the Selden patent holders.

Because his Grandfather's shops employed about a half of all labor in La Porte, Grandfather's his choice of workmen had much to do with setting the distinctive character of the town and the high proportion of home-owners. He at first preferred South Germans but later took in North Germans who came to the Middle West in great numbers just after the Civil War. Some who found employment with him wrote to relatives, who likewise left the old country and settled in LaPorte. Moving to a strange land and ignorant of its language, living under near-pioneer conditions and performing the less sought-after manual work, one German family naturally turned to another for help and companionship. And as North Germany was more populous, the North Germans equaled and out-numbered the South Germans in my Grandfather's employ. All of this inspired such a protective clannishness that Meinrad Rumely's first employees became also family friends and remained so until his death. Some worked thirty and forty years in the Rumely shops. Sons and grandsons followed their parents, and this continuity of work and possession of skill furnished top-grade foreman material when Rumely threshing machine and engine plants expanded.12

During the Franco-Prussian War of 1870, a hereditary antipathy to Prussia inclined many Rumely South German employees to sympathy with France. One noontime after Grandfather had just hired a recent immigrant, he heard a big hubbub in front of the factory. Every window was filled with shouting men watching a South German in the street below beating up the new man. After Grandfather stopped the fight and inquired its cause, his older worker exclaimed, "Meinrad, don't you know what you put to work with us? This fellow is a Prussian!"

Grandfather had few labor problems. Even when several hundred names were on his payroll, he had personally chose and trained for special jobs the more competent men, a grant of opportunity to men of ability that kept morale and incentive at high level.13 Sam Hoover, who worked in a small shop by himself was promised a lifetime job. When my father passed control of the Rumely Company to me, he said, "Your grandfather said as long as Sam Hoover lives and works here, he must earn more money than anyone else in the factory." Hoover operated a big boring mill and special machine, and he was so habituated to its various sounds that he could fall asleep and never fail to wake up to put on another fly-wheel when a cut was ended. Awake or asleep, jolly old Sam Hoover's skill was worth all the extra wages paid him.
To men who showed promise of ability after their hiring, Grandfather said "Now, you save $400. When you have it, come to me, and I'll take you to a bank and you can build a home."

put up $1200 or $1300, and the combined total of some $1600 was enough in those comparatively uninflated days to buy a half or a quarter acre of land and cover building costs of a home.

Grandfather always insisted upon every man keeping a cow and having enough backyard for a garden. At that time, La Porte had high board sidewalks, and cows grazed placidly in the streets and walked majestically down to the lake for water. By the 1890's, the town had outgrown being an open pasture for cows, but Grandfather wouldn't admit it. One year while he was away at Atlantic City, Mayor E. H. [Emmet Hoyt] Scott,14 my father, and my uncle William Rumely secured passage of an ordinance which ruled cows off the streets. When he returned, Grandfather was indignant and he was more indignant, drawing upon the most emphatic expressions in both German and English, when he heard that two of his sons had a part in this innovation. He scolded bi-lingually for weeks, until it occurred to him to buy ten and twenty-acre pasturage at various edges of the town and tell the workmen to put their cows out to the grasslands he had bought. In that way he solved the problem and temporarily was content.

A dozen years ago In 1934 when visiting Binghamton, N.Y., George Johnson described to me the home-ownership policy of Endicott-Johnson shoe factory. He found that when the great depression of '29-'33 came, those workers owning their own home could survive economically even when cut down to two and three days of work. Others who rented their homes couldn't do with less than four days a week, even in the depression. The home owners had gardens. Their taxes were less than rent; and home ownership was a major factor in building the stability of the Endicott-Johnson working force. I found George Johnson's ideas exactly those that Grandfather had put into effect years almost two generations before.

There is no reason why these ideas should not prevail today. For ownership of a home and a piece of ground is the best guarantee for survival of the sturdy American spirit. For a man who has saved up to build and possess his own home, who digs in his own soil and enjoys the harvest whether it is food or flowers for his own table, can't have much truck with the Marxian idea of common ownership. Nor can any man come from a fertile field and sing with a straight face the fist-clenching summons of L'Internationalle, "Arise ye prisoners of

June 21, 1924: "he was one of the most efficient executives the city ever had, managing municipal affairs with system, dispatch and untiring devotion to the general good." See also Daniels, A Twentieth Century History and Biographical Record of LaPorte County. Indiana, 423.
starvation."15

Karl Marx and [Friedrich] Engels brought out their Communist Manifesto in 1848. Hardly was the red ink dried on that document before the Meinrad Rumeleys had the answer: Every man a capitalist; what was needed was not the end of the capitalist system, but more of it.

What Grandfather Meinrad practiced is sneered at in some circles as "paternalism" and it is even suggested that the motivating cause was to secure contentment of workers without raising wages. Actually what Grandfather was doing was to encourage self-reliance and the good citizenship which comes from a stable population. And here is the chief defect of the trade union movement in this country. Although Trade union leadership has rightly sought higher wage rates and improved working conditions. It has done little to encourage home ownership and more contented living conditions.
CHAPTER 3

Just as a river can be traced back to many sources, so it is possible to identify early influences which shape the character and even the life-course of a human being. It was not foreordained that most of my career should be connected with feeding the body and the mind. At first thought, there seems to be little connection between my development of power plowing which made possible intensive wheat cultivation and my pioneering in vitamins. Yet, both served a common purpose: nutrition. Nor is there much obvious similarity between getting sleepy schoolboys out of bed on cold mornings and in mailing to a million and a half intelligent American citizens an urgent warning against perils of inflation or against a bureaucratic grab for power. Yet both activities had the same aim: implanting an idea.

None of these interests could be foreseen when I was a very small boy. Nor was any conscious effort made to lead me into such channels. Nevertheless, had it not been for Grandfather and Grandmother Rumely and Grandmother Zimmerman, my life in all probability would have taken a different course.

Grandmother Zimmerman, my mother's mother, had what in those days was known as "second sight." My mother inherited it as

Arise, ye prisoners of starvation, Arise, ye wretched of the earth, For justice thunders condemnation—A better world's in birth. John Bartlett, Familiar Quotations … (14th ed., Boston, 1968), 680.
"intuition," and I and some of my friends have experimented with it as "extra-sensory perception." Grandmother was born Ludwina Sweitzer in a Rhine Valley village from which one could see the Black Forest mountains and the beautiful lace-like stone spire of Freiberg Cathedral. In the late 1840's she left home for America with one of her brothers. When the day came for parting she clung to her mother and refused to climb into the loaded wagon. Finally the mayor of the village Waltershoven thrust himself between her and her mother and said, "You decided you wanted to go; now go!" Weeping, she was separated from her mother and, as she feared, she never saw her again.
In La Porte years later, after her marriage, Grandmother Zimmerman awoke in the middle of the night terrified. "My mother just walked into the room," she told her husband. "Mother is dead!"

Husband and wife stopped the clock and saw the priest the next morning. Weeks later, a letter came from the old country: Mother Sweitzer had died on that date but at an hour different from the one at which the clock stopped. But when the difference in time between LaPorte and the Rhineland was calculated, the old lady had died at the exact time when the Zimmermans stopped the clock.

Grandfather Franz Zimmerman died before I was born. He was County Sheriff and during the Civil War was a commissioned officer in charge of drafting soldiers in the LaPorte area. His sword and uniform are now in the Historical Society museum in LaPorte's courthouse.

Left a widow with four youngsters, Grandmother Zimmerman took in washing for awhile and had a desperately hard time until the children were old enough to help. Although she lived to be 90?, I never saw her sit with folded hands outside of except in church. George, the eldest of her children eventually became superintendent of Emmett Hoyt Scott's wheel factory.16 Next was Margaret, my mother. Then came Ludwina, who became Sister Vincent a nun Leo House. Her departure from LaPorte had some of the overtones of the scene when her mother left her Rhineland village. This time, I was the hysterical performer. All of seven five years old, I advanced upon her with a clothesline and cried, "You come out in the yard! I'm going to tie you up so you can't get away."

Blessed with common sense and great executive ability, Sister Vincent rose in her Order the Sisters of St. Agnes to become head of Leo House in New York City. At first down on the Battery and later on West 23rd Street, Leo House was a place where Catholic emigrants,
16 Emmet Hoyt Scott and William Niles, his brother-in-law, established the Niles and Scott Wheel Factory in La Porte, and the business was successful in the manufacture of wheels and hubs from 1876 until its sale to the stockholders in 1889.
fresh from Ellis Island, could stay a day or two to get their bearings before proceeding to their new homes in the West. When flood tide of immigration later subsided, Leo House became a home for single girls away from their families and a stop-over for Catholics returning to the old country for a visit.

Uncle Frank Zimmerman, Grandmother's youngest son, was very kind to me. He introduced me to the outdoor life which my father never fancied and Grandfather Rumely was too busy to enjoy. I helped him build a boat in the Zimmerman cellar and he gave me the key to his boathouse on Clear Lake. For hunting trips, he loaded his own shells and every season brought home a dozen wild ducks, maybe a goose or two and plenty of squirrel and rabbit.

Because of Uncle Frank and his mother, I liked to visit the Zimmerman house. "Stay for dinner," she would urge and in winter she'd say, "You stay and sleep here." I liked that because Grandmother had feather beds, and half an hour before bedtime she heated a soap-stone, wrapped it in a blanket and put it in the bed. And then in the morning, in a kitchen aromatic with flowering geraniums and amaryllis, she cooked double-yolk eggs which she saved for me. To this day, I remember her buckwheat pancakes cooked with elderberry blossoms and spread with syrup from sorghum or from LaPorte maple trees.

My arrivel in this world, February 28, 1882, was an event of understandable importance to my parents. Although it was naturally of enormous consequence for me, at the time I was not aware of it, but the consequence was eheightened heightened by the fact that I had the good fortune to be Meinrad Rumely's first living grandchild—and a boy at that.

What initiative and stubborn drive I have was initially inspired by my parents. One encouraged it, and the fact that the other discouraged it seemed to be an equal stimulus. My father, Joseph J. Rumely, was dark-eyed and resembled his Alsatian mother. He was kindly and religious. Never in my life did I hear him speak harshly and his direct influence was one of kindness and love. Yet with all his kindness there was a sense of restraint about him. He was fearful of the sports that I, as a young boy, wished to engage in. He did not want me to swim in deep water and that I found out was the place where swimming was best and most fun. When I was about 11 or 12 he did not want me to take long trips alone with dog and gun in the Kankakee marsh to hunt; that made hunting all the more attractive. In fact, my father wanted me to remain near home and in the safety of our own yard, whereas my impulses and instincts led me to go out and take chances and do things I was interested in.

My mother, on the other hand, gave us children great freedom with a word of guidance or restraint at just the right moment. Having been a tomboy with her brothers at a time when LaPorte was a pioneering city she knew what life was like around the places where we went Saturdays to play. She had remarkable intuition; I always felt she could read our thoughts. The greatest thrill in skating in my boyhood days was on the "bender" ice of Clear Lake—ice so thin that it bent under our weights. Of course, sometimes the "bender" broke. Then we scampered down to the factory where we stood in front of a hot blower until thoroughly dried out. But that never deceived my mother when we came home. Invariably she said "So, another ducking." She could size up people so well that Grandfather frequently spent a half hour with her talking over his plans and asking her judgment about people. The priests likewise came over to discuss with her some problem of the congregation.

My father's chief hobby was music. He was an accomplished violinist, and before his marriage he played at festivals and concerts and sometimes at dances. He always took an interest in us children—bathing us, reading to us, and organizing musical evenings. The signal for such an occasion was when Father reached for his violin case, removed the violin, which he rubbed down with a silk handkerchief, rubbed his bow with rosin, and then called for an "A" on the piano. He played the violin and the whole family sang.

Father also sang in the choir. At one time or another all my brothers and I were church acolytes. Father was proud of his large family and looked down happily from the choirloft when eight or nine Rumelys filed into church, "in a body" as he used to say, and filled two pews. "Joe," his friends said, "you look too young for such a flock."

Although Father was the eldest child and grew up while German was the language of my grandfather's home, English became the principal tongue for him and his brothers, and after they had gone through school and college they lost even their facility for speaking German. But since I, the eldest grandchild spent so much time with my grandparents, I was the only native-born member of the family who spoke German fluently and readily.

My father grew up in LaPorte and after going through parochial school was one of the earliest students at Notre Dame where he took the commercial course. After an apprenticeship in Grandfather's shop, he entered the office, became bookkeeper, and then treasurer and took over financial management of the business. The latter was no mere counting room activity, for the implement business of those days had a banking side with the general practice of extending credit to farmers unable to pay for their machinery in cash.

div.p: My mother maintained the discipline of the family. Occasionally, if some serious offense had been committed, she earmarked the culprit for a spanking, which consisted of Father taking off a slipper and paddling an up-ended offspring without much enthusiasm. When I left home to study in Europe, what I thought I knew at the mature age of 18 about the education and upbringing of children has never since been equalled. I made my parents promise that they would never apply slipper or shingle to my younger brothers and sisters.

It was a promise which they kept—but regretfully. My younger sister Cecelia recalls lying in bed and hearing rueful voices floating up from the living room below: "If only we hadn't promised Edward not to give that child a spanking. She surely needs one now!" But my brother Joe had not made such a promise and he was not only able but willing to do the needful.

The pattern of home life of my Grandmothers Rumely and Zimmerman carried over into our home where it was expected that everyone helped everybody else to do the work about the place. Since the death of her husband Grandmother Zimmerman had to manage the family and she was a good manager. One by one the children took the responsibility and worked with her.

So, too, did Mother handle her large family of 12 by making the older children look after and help with the younger ones. As the eldest child I had the longest term of service and my job included preparing milk bottles for the babies and working up the formula as their ages changed. One of my jobs was to take my four brothers down for a hair cut at the switch tower at the intersection of the Pere Marquette and New York Central. The tower was operated by a railroad man named Miller, who had been run over by a train and lost one leg. And as a sideline to his switching and signaling he took on hair cutting. The barber chair was a tree trunk that had been cut to a yard length while the barber sat on a higher stool with his one leg dangling and did the job of hair cutting. When a train whistled he hippety hopped over with one leg and a crutch to pull the levers and switch the signals and then came back to his tonsorial art.

This stretch of railroad has become is the main line of the New York Central and passenger trains now whizz through at 70 miles an hour. Even then it was one of the busiest in the United States, and freight and express trains east and west bound rolled through at five fifteen minute intervals. It therefore took longer to have hair cuts than in the ordinary barbershop. But the place was more interesting to wide-eyed youngsters, and instead of charging 15¢ a haircut, as did the more fashionable barbers uptown, Mr. Miller gave us a per capita wholesale price of ten cents.

By helping mother in the kitchen, I learned to cook, pack and can fruit and preserve vegetables for the winter. We generally had one girl in the kitchen as a helper. Because Mother was known throughout LaPorte to be a good cook and housekeeper other mothers urged her to take their daughters in and train them. And when the hired girl was out on Thursday or Sunday evenings it was my job to get supper which usually consisted of fried potatoes and eggs, or in wintertime homemade sausage.

Mother baked from 12 to 20 large loaves of bread for Saturday and sometimes on that day I also baked a cake. She set aside part of the bread dough for cinnamon cake and long coffee cake spread with sugar and cinnamon. Four or five times a week we had pies—three large pies at one meal, and enough left for any tramp who should knock at the door. Being a railroad junction, LaPorte was favorite stopover for hoboes, who scrawled chalk marks on trees and the sidewalk in front of our house informing other knights of the road that there was good vittles inside in return for very little work at the woodpile.

We sat in the dining room at a long rectangular table, Father at the head with a mound of soup and dinner plates in front of him. The youngest child sat between Father and Mother, the second youngest child next to Father and I was next in line. Joe sat next to me, Leo beyond him, then Cornelius and so according to age around the table until the third youngest child at the other side of Mother.

Breakfast was about 7:45, usually oatmeal, bacon and eggs, sausage and eggs; in wintertime we had large quantities of salt mackeral—three or four of which made a breakfast with boiled potatoes. The children were all permitted tea and coffee but they also drank a large quantity of milk—a pitcher of which was on the table at every meal.

At midday there was soup, in which Mother was a great believer, and which Father ladled from a big tureen. She would buy eight to ten pounds of bones which she would boil for a long time and then have soup of various flavors, frequently noodle soup for her mother was an expert noodle-maker. Grandmother Zimmerman rolled the batter extremely thin and then cut her noodles into fine hairlike strips for soup. As for meats, we had round steak, roast beef, roast ham, occasionally leg of lamb, frequently chicken and, not so often, pork chops.

Each winter Father bought two large hogs, and the entire hog—ham and tenderloin—was worked into sausage, smoked by old Mr. Zech, whose pet names for his good-natured wife were "Dumbe Frau"
and "Alte Kuh."17 Father would buy 24 hams at a time and hang them in the attic. He was an excellent provider and enjoyed nothing better than going to the grocery store and buying a large quantity of food and sending it home. He would buy a whole bunch of bananas or a crate of oranges. The bananas were put in a closet and we children were allowed to run in whenever we wanted to and take one or two off. During the winter two or three barrels of oysters came from Chesapeake Bay, and it was my job to open them.

Supper was generally fried potatoes with fried apple slices and ham and eggs in one form or another, also home-canned fruit. For supper we had an abundance of home-canned foods. Our cellar was stocked in the fall with apples, potatoes, and endive, celery and cabbage. Enough sauerkraut was put up in ten gallon jars to last through the entire winter. Apple butter was made by Grandmother Rumely in a copper kettle outdoors and sent to us, and Mother put up a delicious tomato preserve in 40 or 50 two-quart jars.

For a change from this routine I used to go over to Grandmother Rumely's which was the same, only more so. Often I stayed as long as a week at a time. My childhood companion was Uncle Aloysius, my father's brother, who was only six years older than I. I would come out of the house and wave to my mother across the street then go back to my temporary home.

I enjoyed rummaging through her attic which was filled with every kind of heirlooms and toys. One mysterious object was covered with a cloth and Grandmother warned "You must keep away from that." I later found out that it was a still which the Fierstoss family had fashioned on their Canton, Ohio farm and had kept on making their own liquors and brandy just as they had in Alsace, but the revenue officers heard of it and made a raid. The result was a stiff fine, more than the farm could pay, but Grandfather Rumely paid the assessment and took the still with him to LaPorte so that there would be no temptation to use it further.

Grandmother Rumely's family, being Alsatian—a betwixt and between of German-French stock—almost made a cult of good food. I have already recorded how in the 1850's and 60's farmers used to stay at her house willingly for a couple of weeks at a time while waiting with gold in their tobacco sacks for delivery completion of their threshing machines, for there is nothing like the drawing power of good food. St. Ignatius of Loyola, founder of the Jesuit Order, said: "The table must be so good that if members leave they will eat less well and wish to come back."
