div.p: One of those who made a point of returning to Grandmother Rumely's table as often as he could was the greatest trencherman in America. His business card read "James A. Brady," but wherever newspapers were read he was known as "Diamond Jim" Brady. He was then a salesman for Manning Maxwell and Moore, a New York City firm dealing in railroad supplies and other equipment some of which was used by the M. Rumely Company. Either on his way to Chicago or back Diamond Jim made one or two occasional calls at LaPorte. He was a connoisseur and mass consumer of good food. But as an antidote to lobsters and champagne he was particularly fond of Grandmother Rumely's noodles and prunes. When Grandmother heard that Diamond Jim was coming she and my aunts started days ahead preparing the luncheon. I recall one visit when I walked up from the shop between Diamond Jim and Grandfather, on the way to luncheon, and hearing Grandfather say "Now, Jim, don't you make eyes at my daughters when you are out over there." I did not know what Grandfather meant then for it was years later when I went to New York and owner of The [New York Evening] Mail and heard the fabulous stories of Diamond Jim, Lillian Russell and the favored young ladies of the Ziegfield chorus.

My lifelong interest in vitamins and nutrition began in Grandmother Rumely's kitchen. So much is known today about these subjects that it is a wonder to many that the human race got along so well without this supposedly up-to-date scientific knowledge. As a matter of fact, science merely fills in some of the gaps in things about which nature has known all along. It merely supplied the why between cause and effect.

If, for instance, a pint of milk a day is the minimum diet required for healthy Americans, why is it that the Chinese got along for centuries without cows. The secret of the Chinese getting along without milk is the fact that they cook their green foods very lightly without destroying by heavy cooking the beneficial effect of minerals and other compounds and they even sprout their beans to give them more of what is now known as "Vitamin C." But, it will be asked, if green foods contain essential elements for human nutrition why do Eskimoes get along without vegetables of any kind? These northern people get their vitamins from the seal and fish livers. By instinct, meat-eating animals in the jungle and fish in the sea first devour the vitamin entrails before eating the flesh of their prey.

Years before scientists and nutritionists found the explanation, Grandmother Rumely and generations of her people before her knew the beneficial effects of vitamin packed rich (containing) foods. She insisted as a child that I eat carrots. When I went into her yard to play she would say "Now get a couple of carrots and wash them."
The pump was outside the kitchen door and she'd stand there until I washed the carrots; then she'd inspect them to see whether they were clean and then say "Now you eat them before you can play in the yard." If it was wintertime I had to go down cellar where carrots were stowed in sand. Grandmother kept 4 or 5 milch cows, one cow was reserved to furnish milk for her infant grandchildren and this cow had carrots in her food and the milk was kept separate.

Grandmother knew before the nutritionists discovered it that when cows are on dry food the vitamin content of their milk is a fraction of normal. In Berlin more children were sick in hospitals in late winter months while cows were on dry feed but when the cattle went out to the grass meadows the infant morbidity fell rapidly. The University of Minnesota experimenters studying vitamin deficiency in rats endeavored to find out how little milk could be fed them. Suddenly the rats gained weight, yet their milk ration was the same level as before and their other food was unchanged. The only thing that had happened was that three days before the cows supplying the milk had gone on green grass and away from the dry hay of winter.

For after leaving Grandmother Rumely's kitchen green vegetables became part of my daily diet. Years later this was an essential diet at my Interlaken School and so important did I regard this that when I was in New York publishing The Evening Mail, I used to have the Interlaken menus sent me. Once I thought the boys were not eating enough salads and green foods so I wrote a notice to be pinned on the school bulletin board recommending that all eat salads and instructing the cook and the kitchen what I wished done in their preparation. Several years later when government investigators were going through my files during World War I they found on fine carbon paper an extremely suspicious document. Its pretended subject was about eating salads but no newspaper publisher would be writing instructions about salads so the G-men were certain that this communication was the key to an enemy code which they had not yet thus far been able to decipher. Reporter told me[.] Actually this was a code, though not the kind that the Department of Justice sleuths suspected. It was a code for good eating and healthy living.

My education began almost as soon as I crawled out of my cradle. I learned to read when I was three at my father's knee, first picking out the letters and then the words while he was reading his newspaper. When I was four Uncle Frank Zimmerman taught me the multiplication table, one table at a time up to 12. Uncle Frank paid
me 5¢ for each table I learned. My elementary mathematical education therefore cost my Uncle and rewarded me a total of 60¢. I would not go so far as to advocate an educational system in which the teachers pay the pupils, but as an incentive for quick and early learning it has its advantages.

Mother insisted upon our learning to work as soon as we knew how to use our hands. I learned to use tools so early that I cannot remember when I first handled hammer, saw, and file. Each child was expected to do as much as it could perform and Mother implanted early in us the habit of methodical effort which more or less followed us the rest of our lives. She expected as a matter of course that repairs and such simple carpentry work as building a chicken house and elementary plumbing jobs like thawing out frozen pipes would be performed by the children.

One time I was repairing a screen door for my mother at the lumber yard where Uncle Frank Zimmerman was foreman. The door was ready to be brought home but the delivery wagon was not within reach, so I put the door on my shoulders. A couple of boys followed me jeering me for making such a spectacle of myself. Without my knowledge Grandfather had observed and when he saw me next time he said "That was a good thing. Don't be afraid of what other people say." Grandfather never was and I never have. been.

I earned money by spading the garden, delivering milk for Grandmother Rumely, shoveling snow, mowing the lawn. Baby sitting was unpaid, but I worked at it. We had a cradle that rocked; and to rock it in absentia while playing chess with a Catholic priest who lived opposite, I ran a length of binder twine across the street to our veranda and the cradle of my baby sister, Florence. During the first few chessboard moves I pondered against Father Messman's openers, I pulled the string steadily, then stopped. If the baby didn't cry, she was asleep. If she did cry, she needed more rocking, whereupon I pulled hard on the binder cord until the wailing ceased. Traffic at that time of evening wasn't heavy on "C" Street. When an occasional buggy passed, I unloosed the cord, and took up the slack after the vehicle had gone by.

Living across the street from the church, we saw much of the Catholic priests in charge of the parish. Several were close friends of mine, particularly Father Messman, my chess-playing antagonist. I used to take him fishing in the best spots Uncle Frank Zimmerman had shown me. Often I played hookey to do so, but since the school was not a parochial one but a public grammar and high school the good father did not look upon my truancy as much of an offense.

Besides being an altar boy in the church, I helped the priests in more secular ways. In Chesterton they taught me Pedro, a less intellectual
game than chess but an innocent one. On Saturday afternoons when four reverend fathers sat down to play Pedro I was usually frequently there to hold the fifth hand. Hours on end they played— sometimes from noon until 10 or 11 at night with a couple of hours' intermission for church services to hear confessions. Also they poured down their throats stein after stein of beer. What went in had to come out, and when a priest left the table on the latter mission, I, "the fifth hand," picked up his cards and played them.

All Rumelys and Zimmermans were devout Roman Catholics. Grandfather Meinrad was devout in his way; that is, he observed his obligations to the church but tolerated no suggestion of domination by the priests. Walking to church on Sundays he would pull out his watch when the bell rang (and knowing that which the altar boy was ringing it he might say,) "That louse boy is ringing the bell a minute and a half too soon." Having timed himself to arrive at church exactly on the minute, he did not want the bell to be rung too early. When that happened Father Nussbaum heard about it, and, through various channels, so did the altar boy who as often as not was a Rumely.

As the parish grew and overcrowded the church an enlarged sacristy was needed. Grandfather had built a wood addition which had been given a preliminary coat of white. At luncheon one day when I was at Grandfather's house he said that he was going to paint the whole addition for Father Nussbaum. "What color?" asked his daughters. "Why red is a good color" said Grandfather. "It doesn't cost much and it lasts a long time. We'll paint it red." When they mildly suggested other colors Grandfather said "No, we will paint it red." Red paint was a commodity in long supply at the Rumely shops for this was the color which identified over the countryside a Rumely threshing machine. Grandfather's devout daughters did not fancy the idea of the same color as a farm thresher being slapped upon the walls of their church.

So, when Meinrad took his after luncheon nap, one of my aunts beckoned to me and said "Try to persuade Grandfather to paint the church white or cream instead of red. If you do, we'll give you a quarter." When he woke up I said to him "Grandfather, wouldn't white or cream be a good color for the church?" He put his head on one side and looked at me and said "So! You want the church white or cream? I'll paint it white or cream for you."

As I look back, I believe that there was some sort of unconscious struggle between Grandfather Rumely and Grandmother Zimmerman for directing the future career of their first grandchild. Grandmother Zimmerman was devoted to the church. She attended Mass every morning then crossed the street for an hour or two at our house. The
finest career she could imagine was the life of service of a religious. Her one daughter had become a nun, and almost before I was out of my cradle she began expressing her hope that one of her grandchildren, possibly Edward, would become a priest. Grandmother Rumely thought it was a nice idea but she never actually encouraged it. But Grandfather clearly had a notion that I'd be more useful in the factory than in the church.

Almost as soon as I could walk, Grandfather used to take me on his rounds of the factory, my whole hand grasping one of his fingers. With him always on these inspection trips was his black Spitz dog. The dog knew the rounds almost as well as Grandfather, for he preceded his master by some fifty feet or so, a sort of advance warning to the men that Grandfather was coming.

The factory was interesting because so many different kinds of work were going on at the same time. The threshing machines were made of wood, but they had many castings and there was much tinsmith work. And so, there was a wood shop, a tin shop, a paint shop and a foundry. Grandfather explained them all and encouraged my going in the plant to use the tools and material. Once when we were crossing State Street, he told me ‘Now, some day when you are in charge of the plant, here is where the water main runs, and here the sewer runs. So, you should mark the spot in the mind; and when you have control of the plant and ever have to dig up the water main, here is the place to do it.’

On our walks together, Grandfather showed me how the steam engine works. Should we hear an engine operating two blocks away, he made me listen to the exhaust and tell me whether the cut-off had been set high enough, or whether the operator was careless or economical in getting the most power with the least amount of steam. (I was too young to understand the principles he explained but I could identify its effects.)

Also Grandfather watched his boilers. Once he stopped suddenly in the street and said crossly, "That fellow is wasting coal." He walked maybe three blocks to the boiler room, and said to the fireman: "You've been wasting coal. You're too lazy to shovel a little coal in at a time, so you filled the whole firebox and dampened the fire. Now I told you to put two or three shovels full of coal on the fire at once, and you've put on ten." When we got outside I asked "How did you know it?" And he said "Well, I looked at the smokestack."

And so at the tender before I had reached the age of 12 or so, I learned about steam engine operation and fuel economy. When a Rumely steam traction engine was being tested, Grandfather allowed me to come down after school and drive the engine around the block
and up and down the plant yard. The regular model engine had a limited steering gear which could not turn more than 40 or 50 degrees. One day I found a specially built larger sized engine in the yard. Not knowing that its front wheels would move in a right angle, I took this big engine out, delighted that I could handle it. At a certain point, I turned the wheels too far and when the engine pounced out of its course, it cut down a telegraph pole. Then I saw Grandfather in the distance—a distance I had no motive for decreasing. Not knowing how angry he would be, and not wishing the paddling which I knew I deserved, I shut off the engine and ducked. I kept away from Grandfather until he came out of church the next Sunday, because I figured that in his Sunday mood and Sunday clothes with all the church people about, the worst that could happen to me was a scolding. To my surprise all he said was: "You foolish boy! If you'd stayed there I would have shown you how to drive those big engines. Instead, you ran away before I could explain it to you."

Summertime was always a busy season at the shop so that farmers might get their machinery in time for threshing. One midsummer, Grandfather was so busy that he operated the shop on the holy day of the Assumption of the Blessed Virgin, and the boiler exploded. The priest mentioned the incident at length in his sermon the next Sunday. As we walked out of church, I said "Grandfather, did you hear what Father Nussbaum said? He said your boiler blew up because you ran it on a holy day." And Grandfather said, "Eddie, that boiler blew up because there was too much steam in it!"

But I noticed that ever after that, Grandfather never allowed steam pressure to get too high in his boiler. Also that he never again operated the shop on a holy day; he played safe, with fingers crossed on both hands.

Grandfather greatly admired Mayor Scott and thought he had the best head in town not only for civic matters but for mechanical and mathematical problems. Emmet Hoyt Scott was a railroad builder and later an industrialist and banker? in LaPorte who became a close friend of Meinrad.

Grandfather used to say to me: "We'll go down to see Scott. He knows a lot." Grandfather's business was personally owned partnership with a brother, John Rumely, who didn't share Grandfather's ambition. John, however, was an expert pattern maker. In the late 80's Grandfather bought him out for $70,000 and incorporated. The firm had been M. and J. Rumely; it now became M. Rumely Company. The advice to incorporate and some guidance in putting through the corporation was given to Grandfather by E. H. Scott, his friend. Mr. Scott became my friend, too, for he could have opposed my marrying his daughter. But he didn't.

When I was six I was sent to LaPorte's German Catholic Parochial School. This school had all grades, some sixty boys and girls from 5 to 13, in one room. Today's heating engineers would have been pained by the big oak-burner which toasted the nearest pupils and permitted the more remote to shiver in their woolens; and the water pail and dipper which today would be thought were appallingly unsanitary. Recitations were rotated for each grade. In these days of pigeon-holed education there is a lot to be said for the one-room school house. The younger pupils listened to recitations of the grade ahead and the brightest ones were carried ahead faster than they would have been within a single grade. I recall following the two upper grades when I was below them two or three years. When I was eleven I had mastered all the subjects of the school, but I was kept there until my thirteenth year when I was allowed to graduate.

Up to then I had traveled but little. I had seen the World's Fair in Chicago forty sixty miles away and been to South Bend, Michigan City and a few neighboring towns. I had, however, roamed all over parts of LaPorte County hunting, fishing, nut gathering and making experimental trips with new machinery with my grandfather. I knew all the lakes and pools of the surrounding country. And thanks largely to Father Nussbaum, a cultured, educated man from the Rhine region, I became absorbed in science. Father Nussbaum planned to study medicine before he decided to join the priesthood and three or four times a week he would come into the school and lecture to upper classes upon astronomy, botany and zoology on a basis level not included in school textbooks. He was the living personification of the fact that it's the personality of the teacher and not the subject which first appeals to the student.

On my own I began the study of physics particularly electricity. All over the house were battery jars of briny water with signs "do not touch." In a long closet off the living room was a row of drawers to which I had attached wooden knobs. By turning them certain ways, like the combination of a bank vault, they would open and only I knew that secret. When [Guglielmo] Marconi's wireless invention was announced I made a sender and coherer receiver and was able to operate it. 18

At Grandfather's shop I began making various devices of my own and my school friends dubbed me the pattern patent maker because I was always engaged in working out some new mechanical problem. Grandfather did not object, in fact, upheld me when I got into trouble.

list.item: 18 In Chapter 4 words printed in boldface were added to the original manuscript in pica rather than elite type.

div.p: Once when I was about 12,I had the idea of building a rotary engine. Needing a large piece of wood about 3" thick and 2 by 2 feet for the cylinder pattern, I found in the pattern shop a cherry wood plank which William Rumely had stored there for some big pattern job. I sawed off one end of it for my cylinder. Uncle William was indignant and told the pattern maker not to allow me back in the pattern shop. When Grandfather heard this, he countermanded the order and said that he wanted me to finish the pattern; that even if I wasted a little wood it was all right—I'd learn. This experience clouded my relations with William Rumely, I believe, for a long time afterward.

Grandfather was willing to have an idea tested and encouraged me to work out whatever project I had in mind. In those days there was no science of mixing irons. A foundry man had to go by an acquired skill. Mr. Oliver at South Bend, Mr. Studebaker, and my Grandfather often swapped experience for some of their castings. They sent to Scotland for iron to mix in. Sometimes the mixture would go wrong, and then a conference would be called until and the judgment of the visitors used to readjust the mix. Foundry sand was brought in from various nearby sources for the making of cores and the molds in the foundry.

One time I got the notion that it was a great waste of time to make a mold, destroy it after each casting, then make a new one. I had heard that asbestos would stand very high temperatures, and worked out a mold which I expected could be used over and over again, and by mixing sand and fibrous asbestos, a mold that would hold its form. When I poured the mold, I did not take the precaution of having it thoroughly dry, and the moisture formed steam and blew the molten iron out like a flowerpot. One spot of molten iron made a small hole in my cheek. Foreman Jake Graf thought I deserved a spanking. Grandfather, who happened by said "no; the boy has learned a lesson and the next time he'd bake the mold hard enough to drive the water out before pouring hot metal on it." Then Grandfather told me to try it again. I did, and succeeded in making four paperweights with this one mold.

Grandfather would go from one department to the other in the factory. He was so expert a mechanic that wherever a man worked he could instantly ascertain whether the methods were proper; and if not, he would go up and show him how to hold a paint brush, how to set the tool in a lathe. He would look at the mixture of the paint and comment on it to the foreman—if too thick, he would tell him he was wasting paint; if too thin, that he was not getting a coat enough on to stand up. The Rumely separators all were of one color—red, which
was inexpensive and durable and made the separator visible for miles across the country.

The next fall after leaving parochial school I entered the 7th Grade of public school. In about two months the teacher decided I should be moved forward to the 8th Grade. After two months there I was promoted to the pre-high school grade and at the age of 14 entered high school.

Gradually my interest changed from scientific experimentation to one of scientific speculation. I became interested in [Charles] Darwin and [Herbert] Spencer and the theory of evolution. The public library had none of lacked the books upon this subject that I heard about and wished to read. So I went to Grandfather and told him I needed books that I could not get. "Whatever books you promise to read I will pay for. You choose them and put the order in and have them come here and charge us collect. Have them send a bill."

One day a huge box arrived at M. Rumely Company the freight station. The bill of lading was accompanied by a statement came addressed to Grandfather at the office with a charge of $480.00. My horrified father brought the bill home and demanded "What does this mean?"
"Grandfather told me I could order some books," I said.
"But not $480 worth" exclaimed Father "$40 maybe."
"No," I said "he told me to buy the books and whatever books I would read he would pay for." So father hurried down to Grandfather and said "You could not have meant to pay all this."
"Yes," said Grandfather "I did. So you just pay for the books and charge them to me."

The company teamster brought the box home on a Saturday morning. I had not yet unpacked all of them when noon came and Father arrived home. The first book he picked up was "The Evolution of the Idea of God." This title horrified him even more than the $480 bill. But the books were paid for and there was not much he could do about it. Just to sooth his feelings, however, I went through my now small library and those books I thought Father would object to most I turned wrong end to or laid sideways so they were not noticeable.

Meanwhile a priest representing St. Joseph's Academy, a newly established boarding school at Rensselaer, Indiana, visited LaPorte and together with one of our priests impressed my father that this was an excellent institution. Perhaps the book episode had heightened my father's impression that a little more church discipline would be an excellent antidote for the free thinking books. After I had been at Rensselaer a couple of months my brother Joe joined me. The school offered excellent instruction in studies that are deemed important in
Catholic orders and preparations for the priesthood. I studied Latin, Greek and French simultaneously and everything went well at first. We had a great deal of outdoor life and there was an Indian school across the street. The Indians taught us how to hunt down rabbits in the snow by foot. Unable to burrow and disappear the rabbits hid under bushes then ran in circles and if two boys relayed each other one after the other in cutting across the circle, one taking over while the other rested, it was possible to run down a rabbit and kill it. Sometimes three or four of us hunting in a group took ten or fifteen rabbits in a single afternoon.

The school was better curricular-wise than culinary-wise. Despite our rabbit hunting, the food at St. Joseph's was monotonous and not well-balanced. In January an epidemic swept through the school. It was undiagnosed but I know now from the symptoms that it was an outbreak of beri-beri. I returned home in pretty bad shape where I recovered quickly and comfortably on family food.

Father Schweitzer, a cousin of my mother's, who visited us frequently, heard of my illness and insisted that I visit him in lower Wisconsin, at Sinsinnawa Mound where he had one large parish and two mission churches; one of which was at Galena, Ill., the old lead city where Ulysses Grant once lived. The time between February to September that I spent with Father Schweitzer was one of the most enjoyable of my life. My priestly cousin loved poetry and had written some delightful little German nature verses. He loved outdoors and nature, poetry and birds as intensely as any person that I have ever known. He knew every bird in the region, its nesting habits, its song, and would capture one young bird of a kind or a brood, take it home into a cage and rear it. He was most skillful in preparing food for every age of these fledglings and seldom lost a single bird. In one big room the walls were banked with bird cages. In the center of the room he had a piano and he knew how to stimulate the birds into singing, either by playing the piano or whistling.

On the same beautiful hill at Sinsinnawa Mound was a nunnery and a school for girls. The school chaplain became a good friend of ours and we played chess with him often. Also Father Schweitzer and I used to go rabbit hunting and fishing in the side waters of the Mississippi. I made a trap which caught rabbits alive and Sister Dolores, a highly intelligent young nun full of zest who had been teaching me a little extra Latin said she would like to go rabbit hunting with me. At five o'clock one morning we ran the traps each one of which had a rabbit in it (and) we were both happy until we got back to the Mound when the Mother Superior discovered her absence and was scandalized that Sister Dolores had gone out for several hours with a young student whom Father Schweitzer hoped some day might
change his mind and study for the priesthood. She imposed on Sister a penance of a rosary for a half hour each day for two weeks and she recommended that Father Schweitzer think up some proper penance for me. The good Father made the penance something that I had intended to do. My task was to memorize his German nature poetry and recite it to him. Sister Dolores and I were restored to good graces before I left for LaPorte and I was confirmed at Sinsinnawa Mound—one young man at the end of a line of about 35 girls.

While I was still with Father Schweitzer at Sinsinnawa Mound, I decided to enter Notre Dame. My father had studied there, but he objected to my going for reasons he never explained. All I could get out of him was "That's not the place for you." If he feared that I was too independent and likely to get into trouble, his foreboding was correct.

But my mind was set on going to Notre Dame and I packed my things. On the morning of my departure, Father was at home with a cold and I went in to his room to bid him good-bye. "I want you to understand," he said "that you are not going with my consent." But I went and Father later accepted the situation, even going to the trouble a year and a half later to try to intervene in my behalf after I quit the place a few hours before the authorities were to expel me.

At Notre Dame I continued the classical course and got on easily in my studies. By doubling two or three classes into each term I completed seven five Latin courses in three terms. I was an honor student in my second year, and when I got into difficulties with the administration I was to have received the gold medal for highest ranking student. But in addition to the classical course I dabbled in the sciences. My chief recreation was chess at which I became champion.

The $420 480 library I had with me became the center of a group of students interested in the Darwinian theory. Notre Dame had not then accepted the doctrine of evolution and the church disciplined Dr. Zahn for writing his book "Evolution and Dogma" a book favoring the theory of evolution. The preceeding summer I had spent eight weeks reading Herbert Spencer's "First Principles" digesting each paragraph into a sentence or two. Until then no book had influenced my thinking so profoundly. Another book, however, set me off on a temporary tangent. Henry George's "Progress and Poverty" gripped me and filled me with a great enthusiasm for the single tax. I subscribed to "The Public" the Chicago single tax paper edited by Louis
F. Post, who later became Woodrow Wilson's assistant secretary of labor. I met single taxers in the neighborhood of South Bend and I evangelized single tax doctrine to my fellow-students until we formed a Henry George group.

This was not good Catholic doctrine. Father Glynn, New York State priest had been reprimanded for too active an interest in the single tax and the University frowned on the discussion of such a subject. Nevertheless we argued the question in our philosophy classes. With the head of the debating society we organized a single tax debate which we won hands down and glowing reports of these activities appeared in The Scholastic, the college paper, whose editor was a member of our group.

All this did not rest well with James Joseph D[.] Oliver, the forthright South Bend plow-maker. Though not a Catholic he was a friend of Notre Dame and to President (Rev. Andrew) Morrissey19 he doubted the advisability of encouraging college students to become protagonists for Henry George. We heard about this through one of our group who was secretary to the president and told us long before the official notification that we were no longer to be allowed to ride our hobby either in The Scholastic or in the debating society.

Meanwhile, my doubts about becoming a priest increased. At the same time reverend fathers of the Order of Holy Cross who taught at Notre Dame were assuring me that if I joined their Order I would surely become one of the superiors or that if I joined the lay priesthood I would be headed towards a bishopric. Somehow, my English teacher, Austin O'Malley, who later became a physician in Philadelphia, heard of this proselytizing, and gave me subtle warning. He was a cultured man of great intelligence and an able critic of student writing. He knew me and my characteristics well, for while the priests were working on me he wrote on the back of one of my English themes: "You have that obstinate nature and independent viewpoint that will get you into difficulty with the bishop or the head of any Catholic institution with rigid discipline."

I decided to move from Professor Pite's Father [Stanislaus] Fitte Latin class to Professor [John] Ewing's economics class. Old Father Pite Fitte was one of the small group of French priests which held a sort of balance of power between the Germans and the Irish in the Order. The open battleground between the two dominant factions was over prohibition—Germans opposing, Irish ostensibly favoring. When Grandfather visited Notre Dame, Professor [Robert] Hoynes Dean of the Law Department used to bring out a two gallon demijohn
19 The Reverend Andrew Morrissey was the eighth president of Notre Dame, 1893-1905. Arthur J. Hope, C.S.C., Notre Dame: One Hundred Years (rev. ed., Notre Dame, 1948), 252.
from his closet and pour generously both for himself and his LaPorte guest. Father Cavanaugh, also an ardent prohibitionist, likewise brought out his demijohn flask, over which with great presence of mind he put his Grandfather black stovepipe hat when a student entered. The prohibitionists received a temporary set-back after instigating prosecutions against restaurant-owner Nichols who had sold drinks to Notre Dame boys in South Bend. Then one Saturday two Notre Dame professors and a couple of priests came in and ordered drinks served in coffee cups. The waiter, already primed for this occasion, called out to the kitchen in a loud voice "Four double whiskies served in coffee cups." And thus was Nichols revenged.

After the director of studies gave me permission to transfer to Ewing's economics class, Father Pite Fitte was indignant. He became more indignant when other students requested transfers from his class and he brought the case up before President Morrissey. Notre Dame's President, a very well-nourished looking cleric sent for me. Using his big round belly tummy like a bull-dozer, he pushed me against a hot radiator, and laid down the law. "You are a very stubborn young man" he said. Still I refused to go back, I insisted that the transfer had been made regularly, that I had learned everything that Father Pite (Fitte) could teach me in Latin, that Ewing's class was interesting and that I intended to go ahead.

Father Morrissey released me from the radiator. "The Germans put you up to this obstinacy!" he exclaimed. "The Germans put you up to this!" But he did not tell me what was to happen. A few days later my English teacher friend, Dr. O'Malley, called me to one side "There has been a faculty meeting over your case," he said "and the lay teachers have been out-voted by members of the Order who decided if you do not yield by Thursday you will be expelled." He added that I mustn't think that I knew more than the rest of the world and that I would accomplish nothing by obstinacy.

I waited until Wednesday evening, when I ordered a hack from South Bend. A couple of students carried down my trunk and my "dangerous" books, and I left Notre Dame at ten o'clock. The next morning when a university official came to carry out the ultimatum and conduct me before the faculty dean of studies to give me a final choice, he found my room empty.

Back in LaPorte my eleventh hour avoidance of expulsion did not stir my family half as much as my announced intention of continuing my studies in Europe. In great agitation my father went to South Bend the next Sunday to try to patch up matters with the University authorities, but there was a church celebraion going on and he was unable to see the President Morrissey. This proved my chance for after two weeks I won over Grandfather, who said "You'd better wait
until June, then if your father doesn't consent I'll pay your expenses in Europe."
"Why must you go to Europe" Grandmother Rumely asked, arguing strenuously against my trip, "why must you go across the ocean?" "Grandmother," Grandfather said "why did you cross the ocean?"

I proposed to go abroad with a Notre Dame student of whom I had become very fond, Alexander Lattimore. His family escaped the headman's axe in the French Revolution by fleeing to America where they settled in the South and became slave owners, with 800 hundred (100) slaves freed by Lincoln's Emancipation Proclamation.

Lattimore, whose nephew, Owen, achieved considerable notoriety in recent years, was a cultured, poetic esthete. He knew architecture and art and books that I had never heard of. To him I was a ruddy-cheeked prairie boy full of enthusiasm and energy. I had charted my time and planned my studies and reading weeks and months in advance. Lattimore's theory was that everything traveled in a circle, that everything returned to the place from which it started. Why trouble? Live and have a good time on the way. Don't be a boor and gulp the common wine but learn to sip the rarer drink. He led me into his world—we read [Geoffrey] Chaucer, Mathew Arnold and [Richard Henry] Wilde.

Lattimore was a High Church Episcopalian who had been admitted to Notre Dame in the hope that he would become a priest. After I left the University I still had thoughts of continuing my studies for the priesthood. but I had serious thoughts about many of the doctrines and dogmas of the church and I had become thoroughly dissatisfied with conditions limitations that surrounded me at Notre Dame, though as I look back today I was too severe in my criticism and may have been wrong in my judgment of them. Nevertheless, I had made up my mind as the result of reading Herbert Spencer's book on "Education"20 and Jean J. Rousseau's "Emile" that I should some day as Catholic found a school of my own more along my own lines of thought. But as a second alternative to the priesthood preparation for this and coming more and more to the foreground was the thought of the study of medicine.

After long repeated arguments in which my father's judgment wavered from day to day I finally left LaPorte and joined Lattimore on the way east to Washington. There I met Father Godfrey Schilling head of the Franciscan Monastery who invited me to spend my time in Washington with him, where I slept in a cell and observed the life of a Franciscan monk.

list.item: 20 Rumely refers to Herbert Spencer, Education: Intellectual, Moral and Physical (New York, 1900).

div.p: I have never forgotten those three days. Godfrey Schilling was a remarkable man of great insight. He was interested in my plans, in my views about schools that I had attended and my hope of some day to start a school of my own.

"I gather from what you say," he said "that you do not believe many of the tenets of the Church. But when you start to build something like a school you must realize that you are building a human institution in which every human being is a unit. Remember, men are like grains of sand, and the winds of time blow them this way and that. The Church is the only organization which has been able to hold men firm through the centuries. She found the secret of cementing individual sands into blocks of sandstone that are a solid foundation on which to build.

"The wisdom of the Church is based on its knowledge of human nature. It is this knowledge which has enabled her to be the only organization in all history that through the centuries has dealt with the human nature of every race, of every climate and under every condition.

"Look," he continued "colonization in America was mostly by Protestants who had left the Church of Rome. Foremost among these colonies was Massachusetts. Today, Catholics in Massachusetts are 40% and with the birthrate they have it won't be long before Massachusetts is a Catholic state; and what was once a Protestant colony comes into the fold of the Mother Church."∗

"In the Roman world the Church was; in the feudal world, it was; in the modern Democratic world, the Church is. Don't turn lightly from the Church because she treasures 18 centuries of experience with human nature. You could waste your whole life in a futile struggle against such an organization; but work with it, bend it to your purposes, and you will be invincible."

Leaving Washington, Lattimore and I stopped over for a few hours in Philadelphia. We saw on a billboard that [Walker?] White-side was playing in "The Merchant of Venice," so we bought tickets. After the performance we found that there was no train for New York until three in the morning. Having time on our hands and knowing that Ben Franklin was buried in a churchyard, we decided to look up his grave. We located what we thought was the church but in the moonlight could not find the grave. Then I saw another grave surrounded by a high railing. We vaulted the fence and looked at the tombstone. That was not Franklin's grave either. As we walked away a couple of men rushed us and I thought we were being held up.
∗ This was said in 1900. What Father Schilling predicted has since taken place. [The two preceding sentences were located in a footnote in the original manuscript.]
I wrestled with one man, got him out into the street and held him so firmly he could not get away. Lattimore, on the other hand, being of frail physique was easily overpowered whereupon his antagonist blew a whistle. Shortly a police wagon came up and two or three bluecoats jumped out.

I thought they were going to nab our attackers instead of that they held us and hauled us off to a police station. We were thrown into a cell filled with drunks. When we protested strenuously they moved us to an unoccupied women's cell. The gas flickered, the shadows of the bars jumped back and forth, a procession of cockroaches marched up and down the walls and there were two hard board bunks.

The desk sergeant had taken away our pocketbooks which included cash for the trip to Europe, letters of introduction and other papers, but they left Lattimore a pocket edition of Shakespeare's Sonnets—a deluxe printing by [Thomas B.?] Mosher. A women's cell occupied by two frightened young men is not the most exotic setting for enjoyment of these immortal lyrics. But we whiled away the time sure that as soon as morning came the error of our arrest would be understood and corrected.

About eight o'clock I became impatient and rattled the lock on the door. This brought the keeper who struck at my fingers with his club a blow so hard that if I had not withdrawn my hand quickly he would have broken the bones. "That'll teach you to make a noise like that" he said. Later we were taken into the court. One of the men who had rushed us in the graveyard said that he was a watchman at Wanamaker's, had seen us in the churchyard attempting to break a lock on the door. Then frightened by being observed we jumped over the fence and ran until we were overpowered. We tried to explain that we had been looking for the grave of Benjamin Franklin. "Trying to break into church to look for Ben Franklin's grave" exclaimed the Judge "in my many years upon the bench I have heard a good many fish stories but this is the tallest. I am going to hold you for the Grand Jury."

Back in the cell I asked for a lawyer and I was told "you'll have plenty of time before the Grand Jury gets around to your case." About a half hour later we were summoned back to court where the judge told us "I've been thinking things over. You look young and innocent and probably this is your first offense. So I have decided to give you another chance and to release you."

The police gave us back our money and papers and we went to a barbershop to get shaved and washed up after our night in jail. There we saw one of the police sergeants who had been in court. "DO you know what got you out" he asked. "No, I don't" I said.

"After the judge bound you over for the Grand Jury the court officers looked through your papers and found a letter from Father Godfrey Schilling to some prominent Catholics in London. Whereupon a friend of the judge went to him and said ‘Judge, these young fellows certainly know some top level Catholics. You are up for reelection shortly and since the Catholics are against you, you had better be careful in this case.’"
This judge had bound us over for no good reason and had released us for a worse reason—an experience I was to undergo a quarter of a century later in The Mail case.21

I thought this matter over and after we got to England reached the conclusion that something had to be done. So I wrote a letter describing the case to a single tax magazine which had considerable circulation in Philadelphia and I learned afterwards without the slightest regret that this letter had been very embarrassing to the judge.

Delayed a day in our bout with the Philadelphia law we reached New York and put up at Leo House where Sister Vincent was Mother Superior. We booked passage on a slow boat to London. Passengers were several hundred live cattle and 60 humans. Meanwhile my father had been stirred to action by advice from Notre Dame come to the conclusion that he should prevent my going abroad. He hastened to New York. When he arrived at Leo House shortly before noon the porter who had taken our baggage out that morning pointed out to him an Atlantic Transport Liner moving slowly down the North River. Lattimore and I were on board.

Rumely fought the charge and after being sentenced to a year and a day in jail was finally pardoned by President Calvin Coolidge. See James A. Patten and Boyden Sparkes, "In the Wheat Pit," Saturday Evening Post, CC (September 3, 1927), 3-5; (September 17, 1927), 24-25; (October 1, 1927). 22-23; (October 15, 1927), 42-50; (November 5, 1927), 25-29; (November 19, 1927), 38-40; "Organized Leadership: The Story of the Committee for Constitutional Government" (New York, 1944), 14-16.

div.head: The Copperheads: Historical Approaches to Civil War Dissent in the Midwest
div.p: In the folklore of American patriotism the word Copperhead has held a special place of scorn. Once used by Republicans during the Civil War to slander Democrats opposed to Lincoln's war and emancipation policies, the term has become synonymous in the vernacular with traitor or coward. Apparently Clement L. Vallandigham, a leading Copperhead, inspired Edward Everett Hale's paean to the American nation, The Man Without a Country. 1 More recent writers have used the Copperheads as exemplars of evil. As Nathaniel Weyl wrote of them in 1951, "the parallel with the contemporary pro-Soviet conspiracy is evident."2

But folklore is not history, and historical literature dealing with Civil War dissent offers a wide variety of interpretations and moral judgments of the subject. Most scholars have agreed that there was widespread discontent with the war, especially after 1862 and primarily in the Midwest. A few Democratic politicians heatedly denounced the war aims as Republican tyranny and abolitionism. Draft resistance posed some threat to the Union cause, and secret societies were created to fight the Republican party extralegally. At the same time, Republicans capitalized on the "treason" of a small number of Democrats to slander the entire opposition. As the war progressed, Republican campaign hyperbole turned into suppression as dissenters were illegally arrested and Democratic presses were destroyed.

Most historians accept these bare facts regarding the phenomenon of Copperheadism, but the most profound questions surrounding the subject of dissent have yet to be explored sensitively. One central problem—the lack of a working definition for Copperheadism—has its roots in the partisan and perjorative use of the word by Republicans in the Civil War era to describe those suspected of having even the least reservation about the war effort. Historians have described Copperheads variously as advocates of "peace at any price," those who actively encouraged or participated in draft resistance, or loyal Democrats victimized by Republican partisan politics for their grave misgivings about the changes being wrought by the war. To avoid confusion, this essay will use the term only to point out the conceptual limitations it has fostered.

Questions which historians ask about people and events in the past are often as important to the growth of an historical literature

as the empirical data on which that literature is based. This is certainly true in the case of Civil War dissent, where historical study has been strongly influenced by considerations of patriotism and tradition. Inquiry in this field has been dominated by two major types of questions. First, some historians have concentrated on studying dissent mainly in its relation to the Union cause. They have asked whether there was real danger of widespread, active disaffection. They have studied the Republican response to opposition activities and have asked if the extraconstitutional measures taken were justifiable in a war situation. Historians who have posed such questions in the past have usually been highly sympathetic to the war effort. Thus the answers given have generally led to an indictment of the dissenters and at least qualified endorsement of their suppression. Following a somewhat different line of questioning and often appearing more sympathetic to the antiwar group, other historians have studied the economic, social, and political roots of dissent. This approach has dominated the latest research in the field, but its use stretches back to the early part of the twentieth century.

Of the two roads to an understanding of Civil War dissent, the first to appear was that which attempted to assess the relationship of antiwar feeling to the Union cause. Implicit in this approach was an understanding of the most profound institutional conflicts in a democracy. An obvious problem was that of the seemingly subversive use of constitutional liberties during a government's fight for survival. Less obvious and largely ignored was the question of how dissenters reacted to the Lincoln administration's concept of the powers and role of Federal government: both the decision in favor of a war to force Union and also by the powers developed to prosecute that war. Early historians usually just assumed answers to these difficult questions rather than investigating what actually happened.

James Ford Rhodes is a case in point. This great nationalist historian found war resistance to be a tricky challenge to his twin deities of national destiny and the Constitution. On the one hand, a serious antiwar movement would have shaken his thesis of consensus for the Union cause in the North. On the other hand, had there existed no threat to the northern cause from within, it would have been hard to explain Lincoln's use of extraconstitutional power to suppress dissent.3 Rhodes' solution was to stress the seeming threat of disaffection while denying the seriousness of its presence, and to show that Lincoln stretched the Constitution only when he thought that it was in the interest of saving the Union. Though he admitted that "the
3 James Ford Rhodes, History of the United States from the Compromise of 1850 (7 vols., New York, 1899), IV, 227-36. Rhodes found the problem serious enough to employ comparison with the English judicial system.
military commission which tried and sentenced Vallandigham had not a vestige of legal standing" and that "the commutation of the President was likewise vitiated in law," Rhodes nonetheless stressed mitigating circumstances for these actions. He impressed upon the reader that it would be "well to remember" that Lincoln "came to the consideration of the Vallandigham case oppressed with the anxiety at the terrible defeat of the Army of the Potomac at Chancellorsville."4

One need not condemn Rhodes for such pragmatic historical judgment. A government is expected to defend itself in times of crisis. But Rhodes was so caught up in his vision of what America was to become after the war that he gave no notice to the dissenters' vision of the "Union as it was," a conservative conception of what American life should have been. He failed to explore fully the impact of the Civil War for a significant segment of the northern populus.

When Rhodes eventually gave pragmatic approval to the suppression of dissent, it was only after gravely questioning its legal implications. With the coming of the First World War, a number of historians developed a view of Civil War dissent so hostile as to ignore the issue of civil liberties. Scholars such as William A. Dunning and Elbert J. Benton fell victim to the same wartime fears which transformed sauerkraut into victory cabbage. Dunning compared Wood-row Wilson's and Lincoln's methods for dealing with "subversives," using efficiency and adequate legislation as his main standards. Lincoln and the war governors, without the Espionage and Sedition Acts of 1917 and 1918 as aids, had to suppress dangerous elements through makeshift executive power and without clear sanction or precedent. Wilson, on the other hand, had adequate power through legislation and therefore could suppress dissent within "an abiding reign of law."5 This argument stressed legal positivism at the expense of suppression's victims.

Elbert J. Benton, in his Movement for Peace Without Victory During the Civil War, complemented the legalisms of Dunning by lashing out at the Peace Democrats.6 To Benton they represented the gravest threat to the Union cause: "The most dangerous opposition which a cause may have is one which conceals itself, perhaps unconsciously, behind a pacifist group, or any particular group, and makes use of one or the other for partisan ends … Such a party deliberately flouts democracy."7

div.p: The spirit of the First World War did not pervade all Copperhead scholarship. One of the pioneer monographs in the field, Mayo Fesler's "Secret Political Societies in the North during the Civil War," argued more in the tone of Rhodes when it concluded that dissenters failed to "distinguish between partisan politics in time of peace and in time of war." Fesler discounted, as did Rhodes, any real danger of widespread subversion.8 At the same time, he was more realistic about Republican actions than Rhodes. On the subject of Republican charges of treason Fesler asserted that "such statements had more of vote-winning power than truth in them." As for the motivations of Peace Democrats, he stressed partisanship and his judgment that the dissenters were from "the more ignorant portion of the Democratic Party … "9

In later years general histories of the Civil War period have continued to deal with the two major questions of the extent of danger from dissent and the propriety of Republican responses. James G. Randall made a detailed study of civil liberties problems raised by the use of executive powers during the war and concluded that Lincoln limited constitutional liberties only in order to insure the preservation of the Union.10 Yet Randall, like Rhodes and Fesler, thought the dangers of internal dissent were magnified out of proportion to reality in the heat of politics and war. In his Civil War and Reconstruction, he stated that "careful historians do not accept the view that … [the Copperheads] were a dangerous organization of a thoroughly treasonable nature."11

Allan Nevins, in War for the Union, presented similar views in relation to dissent. Nevins questioned the constitutionality of Vallandigham's arrest but also appreciated the circumstances under which Lincoln had to act. He emphasized that the President's duty was "to think first and foremost of the nation's safety … "12 At the same time Nevins discounted any real danger from war dissenters:
It is clear that the danger was by no means so great as the excited governors supposed. Organization of revolt was impossible. Local malcontents could not communicate with each other, could not drill without inviting the attentions of home guards and military, and could find no real leaders. Under these circumstances, sedition was like the ghost in Hamlet; it was here, it was there, it was nowhere.13

Those historians interested in Civil War dissent as it related to the Union have contributed a certain number of levelheaded answers

to the historical literature. With the exception of scholars such as Dunning and Benton, they sensibly assessed the dissenters as being of little immediate danger to the Union cause. They took a common-sense approach to constitutional liberties in time of war by arguing that infringements seemed justifiable in the context of a war for the Union's existence. Yet none of these historians looked very hard at the thoughts and motivations of the dissenters themselves. Most dissent was seen as a product of Democratic partisanship, cowardice, or prosouthern attitudes.

When one raises questions as to the motives of the antiwar elements and the significance of their social, political, and economic outlook in a broader view of American history, regional and state studies of the Civil War era have proved most helpful. The authors of these works usually asked not only how but also why the antiwar movement attempted to counter war policies. Copperheadism was explained not only in terms of selfish partisanship and cowardice, but in addition as a product of economic interest, racial fears, and western sectional identity. Thus dissent could be viewed in terms of American life before and after the war.

Not all state and regional studies followed this approach. Works by Arthur C. Cole and William Dudley Foulke, for instance, reviewed the same questions as Rhodes, Fesler, and Nevins. Era of the Civil War, Cole's history of Illinois, written during the First World War, often spoke harshly of the dissenters. The author attributed antiwar activities almost solely to prosouthern sentiment which was "often translated into action, varying from cheers for Jefferson Davis to active aid for the rebel cause."14 Though Cole himself had some question about the wisdom of suppression, he found sincere fear to be behind arbitrary arrests and the destruction of presses: "The justification for drastic action by individuals or by government authorities was found in the so-called ‘crimes of the copperheads,’ which terrorized not only individuals but whole communities. They were so numerous and varied that there was a fearful uncertainty as to when and how the copperheads might next strike."15

William Dudley Foulke, in his influential writings on Indiana war governor Oliver P. Morton, approached antiwar activities with a mixture of acceptance of their dangerous nature and outright ridicule. In dealing with the largely mythical "Northwest Conspiracy" Foulke accepted every damaging bit of evidence to show the dangerous intentions of the Sons of Liberty, an antiwar group,16 While emphasizing

their danger, however, he nonetheless turned to strained ridicule through literary allusion in an attempt to portray the enemy within as buffoons: "Rozinante [and] Mambrino's helmet … were essentially no fitter subjects for satire than the midnight initiators in Indianapolis …"17

Cole and Foulke have been exceptions, however, and most other prominent regional and state historians have had more interesting things to say about antiwar activities. In the regional group Henry Clyde Hubbart was one of the first midwestern scholars to see a general pattern for dissent in that region. In "Pro-Southern Influence in the Free West, 1840-65" and The Older Middle West he argued that midwestern Democrats were zealously prowestern and were attempting to guard their way of life from both eastern and southern incursions.18 Hubbart attributed a distinct ideology to the western Democracy and those who would become dissenters: they "championed a western version of the rights of man, of Jeffersonian liberty, and agrarianism and of the right of revolution."19 Accordingly, Copperheadism "appeared to be the manner in which thwarted Westerners showed their sectional discontent."20 Though Republicans attempted to use western sectionalism as an issue before and during the war, they were seriously hindered by the strong identity that Republicanism had with eastern economic interests and New England abolitionism.21

In the field of economic history, regional scholars also showed that those who urged peace did not do so because they were especially dependent on the South for economic well being; rather it was because the West played an important role in the economic life of both South and East, and the war temporarily made that position impossible. Albert L. Kohlmeier's The Old Northwest as the Keystone of the Arch of American Federal Union carefully documented what the title stated—that midwesterners had a vital interest in keeping the Union together. Unfortunately Kohlmeier's study did not include an explanation as to why Democrats and Republicans envisioned such different paths toward Union. He did, however, establish that a western

Another midwestern scholar, Charles R. Wilson, considered particularly the charges of prosouthern economic motives in antiwar sentiment.23 Wilson argued that expanding industry and increased trade with the East suggested that assumptions as to Cincinnati's prosouthern sympathies were "largely legendary."24 According to Wilson it was true that much western trade did go south, but the fact that the West traded with both regions and manufactured as well allowed it to be independent: "Actually, then, no colorless subserviency to the South characterized pre-war Cincinnati. It spoke for itself, and it spoke in terms of a driving, booming, independent westernism which wore no man's collar."25

Departing from economic history, a recent work by V. Jacque Voegeli, Free but Not Equal, discussed the prevalent racism of the Midwest during the Civil War and related it both to Republican and Democratic politics. Voegeli stressed the Negrophobic elements of Democratic campaigns and opposition to the war after the Emancipation Proclamation, but he also showed that racism was not limited to the Democrats. Free but Not Equal thus reinforced the importance of western sectionalism in a rather odd way: Voegeli showed that while both parties had strains of Negrophobia, only the Democrats could take full advantage of midwestern racism because the local Republicans were tied to their eastern brethren who included a radical fringe. If Republicans wished to exploit midwesterner's racial attitudes, they had to do more than make defensive statements which explained away the abolitionist wing of the party. In a sense then, Negrophobia's relation to dissent had to be read both as an independent force and as a political tool to pin the abolitionist label on the Republican party.26

James A. Woodburn's "Party Politics in Indiana During the Civil War," one of the first serious looks at Civil War politics on a local level since that war ended, contained a startling number of insights which would be exploited in future years. Woodburn asserted at the outset that both parties professed and practiced loyalty to the Union. In the case of the Democrats, this devotion sometimes took "a peculiar, even a questionable turn." But Woodburn emphasized that the Democratic opposition to the war opposed not the Union cause, but the kind of Union which they saw the Republicans building.27 According to Woodburn, antiabolitionist feelings, conservative constitutionalism, and partisanship all played major roles in creating opposition to the Republican administration's war policies. He saw all of these reasons as basically negative and concluded that the Democrats had really no constructive critique of the crisis at hand.28 Even so, his article gave more of an airing of Democratic views than most other unfriendly studies.

Written a number of years later, the second of Logan Esarey's two volume History of Indiana offered a similar but somewhat inconsistent view of antiwar activities in that state. He began by generalizing that although resistance to the war effort existed in all parts of the state, "the old Jacksonian Democracy stood firm for the Union." At the same time he noted that "among the people of Indiana there was at all times considerable opposition to the war." Esarey attributed most of this opposition to partisan politics, thus indicting the Democrats whom he also called loyal.29 He then went into a lengthy description of the marginal Knights of the Golden Circle and its secret plots as if it were representative of dissent in general.30 With reference to the Knights Esarey concluded that it was "doubtful if Governor Morton was ever seriously alarmed at their plots and certainly history has paid the poltroons entirely too much attention."31

Emma Lou Thornbrough's Indiana in the Civil War Era, the most recent and most comprehensive study to appear on the subject thus far, summed up the problems inherent in dealing with Civil War dissenters. Miss Thornbrough pointed out the delicate .problem of deciding whether the dissenters were indeed "disloyal" but came to no real conclusion on the matter.35 The book excellently reviewed the accomplishments of past scholars by describing all the reasons why different individuals and groups opposed either Governor Morton or the war effort in general. Included were economic grievances, infringement on civil liberties, Negrophobia, and the fear of New England dominance. Miss Thornbrough even put some stress on dissent outside the normal political sphere.36

But state studies, from Woodburn to Thornbrough, concentrated largely on dissent channeled through the Democratic party. Some stressed the unreasoned partisanship of the Democratic side during wartime, others the exaggerated charges of treason hurled by the Republicans. Much has thereby been clarified as to the loyalty and actions of those Democratic politicians who voiced reservations about Republican war policy. It has been made clear that a good deal of the dissenters' political importance came through the use made of them by Republican politicians—both during and after the war. But what of the antiwar sentiment expressed through the varied forms of resistance to the draft? What of the strong disillusion with the Republican war policies which had only partial expression through the election of 1862? And what of the worth of that "Union as it was" which the dissenters mourned ? Little in the way of analysis of such points has come from the largely politically oriented state studies.

Answers to these questions would seem most likely to come from studies devoted primarily to the dissenters themselves, but so far the results have been mixed. The first major work on the dissenters, Wood Gray's Hidden Civil War, made some headway but was unfortunately

Published just after Pearl Harbor, Hidden Civil War began with a lesson: "In any future crisis this nation may almost certainly expect to be once more face to face with some aspect of defeatism … A wise people learns from such experience."37 Gray described the Copperhead defeatists as "narrow, clinging to prejudice as though it were principle, capable of plausible but twisted logic …"38

Yet to judge Gray's scholarship by such conclusions would be to distort and underrate his contribution. In the pages between his virulent though informative introduction and his generally hostile conclusion, he soberly discussed the roots of discontent with the war, the extent and importance of Republican harrassment and suppression, and the significance of changes in northern progress on the battlefield. He particularly pointed out the bitter reaction to emancipation policies, noting that midwesterners feared that "the bars would be lowered for a horde of Negroes to sweep into the section."39

Gray's harsh judgment of Copperhead defeatists thus tended to be modified by the evidence he presented showing the stresses and suppression under which antiwar advocates lived. He reported throughout the book major and minor incidences of harrassment through mob violence, arrests, and in the case of Vallandigham, even exile from the North.40 It was this suppression, Gray argued, that led to the formation of secret societies such as the Knights of the Golden Circle and the Sons of Liberty. They were created "at first largely as a means of self-protection and to some extent for revenge."41 To balance the picture he also reported Democratic retaliation with mob action.42 But even after this insightful and comprehensive look at antiwar sentiment Gray still felt the need to conclude that "the great majority of the people, often misled and given to alternate excesses of optimism and despair, were in the end willing to carry the war through to its close."43

If patriotic moralisms sometimes got in the way of Gray's otherwise competent research, they clearly dominated George Fort Milton's Abraham Lincoln and the Fifth Column. Milton made more than concessions to the wartime situation. He turned the story of Copperheadism into a patriotic morality play. The issues of 1861 and 1942 were the same: "In the Civil War, as in our war of today, we find the same common denominators. Nobility and heroism are hardy perennails—and

As a revisionist Civil War historian, Milton found both Radical Republicans and Peace Democrats base and cowardly. On the Republican side of the "Fifth Column" Charles Sumner and Thaddeus Stevens were "as deeply committed to a secret revolution as they were to Federal successes on the battlefield."45 On the Democratic side those who did not fully stand by the Union insidiously plotted against the cause of the boys in blue. Thus Milton treated Vallandigham's political career under the chapter heading "Anatomy of Treason."46 Fernando Wood, Peace Democrat and mayor of New York "made a few statements of his veneration for the dear old flag," Milton snidely noted, "and then began to fill his paper with innuendo and subversive propaganda."47

The latest full scale study of the dissenters, Frank Klement's The Copperheads in the Middle West, countered the kind of treatment Milton gave to the antiwar faction.48 Klement did, in fact, produce a detailed study of dissent, taking the same basic approach as the regional and state studies of the Civil War era. He saw men opposing the war for economic reasons, for racist reasons, and for fear of eastern dominance.49 He made explicit one theme which had remained in the background, and its use was perhaps the chief contribution of his work. This was the idea of the dissenter as arch-conservative: "In a sense, those Democrats were conservatives; they thought that the wheel of revolution turned too far. Their wartime slogan, ‘The Constitution as it is, the Union as it was,’ proved that they looked toward the past and feared the changes which the war foisted upon the country."50 Yet Klement treated Copperhead and Peace Democrat as synonyms, which of course was the way many of the Republicans had used the terms during the war period. Klement showed the Copperheads not to be treasonous at all because the Peace Democrats were not treasonous. The group of extrapolitical war resisters who interfered with war plans by fighting the draft, for instance, found no place in Klement's consideration of the Copperheads. Copperheads

Instead of dealing with the real war resistance, Klement fell back to correcting the age old slander of Democrats. He saw the process of revision in two steps. First of all, he stated, the historical literature "still viewed … [them] as men whose hearts were black, whose blood was yellow, and whose minds were blank."52 His task was to reveal that the Copperheads were really "human beings—motivated by the same wants and emotions that have been possessed by people throughout the ages …"53 It must be noted at this point that one of Klement's predecessors, Gray, made almost exactly the same remark in The Hidden Civil War: "All opponents of the war had at least one thing in common: they were human beings acting from human motives."54

After establishing that the Copperheads were human beings, Klement completed his revision by linking Copperheadism with both protoagrarian and backward looking Jacksonian ideals.55 Thus Klement's contribution turned out to be an extended monograph continually exploiting links between anti-Republican sentiment and agrarian Jacksonianism, and filling in interesting details on various dissenters, while claiming to do much more. Klement himself never tried to put his own research into any historiographical context. He pointed with pride to the fact that "readers who check the footnotes will notice that this study is based, practically in entirety, upon primary sources";56 left unanswered was the extent to which Klement has brought new understanding to the Civil War peace movement.

An affirmation of the Klement approach can be found in Richard Curry's "The Union As It Was: A Critique of Recent Interpretations of the ‘Copperheads.’" Curry dismissed charges of resistance and disloyalty in the same way as Klement. But whereas Klement only alluded to the previous historical treatment of the antiwar movement, Curry specifically analyzed the literature. His synthetic categories and distortions pointed out the essential evasion of his position.57

The traditionalists supposedly restated the case of the "Radical Republicans against their conservative antagonists."59 The revisionists, however, "reject[ed] the idea of conspiracy, treason, or treasonable intent on the part of significant numbers of northern Democrats."60 The revisionists obviously carried the day in Curry's view, and the essay then went on to treat issues debated among the revisionists themselves. Differences of opinion on the Granger-Copperhead connection, economic and demographic factors, and other topics were well treated in the remainder of the article.61

Curry's treatment of the disloyalty problem, however, was both brief and misleading. In the traditionalist group were bunched Gray and Milton,62 who supposedly both took a dim view of their Copperhead subjects. But the appraisals Gray and Milton gave the Copperhead phenomenon varied so widely that it would hardly be justifiable to put them in the same analytical group. Gray saw Copperheadism as a mass socio-psychological malaise, whereas Milton couched his argument in epithets such as coward or traitor and only dealt with a small number of people. In any case, it would certainly be unfair to make the revisionist Milton a spiritual heir of the Radical Republicans he so abhorred.

Nonetheless, Curry went on to use Gray's Hidden Civil War as the exemplar of traditionalist prejudices and exaggerations about the Copperhead threat. But it was Curry who exaggerated to make his point. For example, he paraphrased and quoted Gray to the effect that after Vallandigham lost the 1863 election for governor of Ohio, "many Peace Democrats at last became convinced that ‘they must resort to revolution if they were to succeed in realizing their aims.’ "63 If Gray had actually made such a statement, it would have indeed been an exaggeration of the small popular interest in actual revolution.
