div.head: Lewis and Clark: Pioneering Naturalists. By Paul Russell Cutright. (Urbana: University of Illinois Press, 1969. Pp. xiii, 506. Illustrations, notes, appendices, bibliography, index. $12.50.)
div.p: Most Americans first heard of Lewis and Clark as school children, and the facts most likely to be remembered were that they were the first white men to cross the Rocky Mountains and that they had an Indian girl as a guide. Students generally thought of such explorers as intrepid adventurers who travelled to unknown lands chiefly for excitement. That they might have collected scientific specimens and recorded valuable data never occurred to most people. Only scientists such as Alexander von Humboldt and Charles Darwin did that.

It therefore came as a pleasant surprise to this reviewer in later years to learn that Lewis and Clark had been charged by President Thomas Jefferson to make note of the natural features of the country, including the plants and animals, and to find that they had collected specimens, some of which were still in existence. In connection with a brief paper on the botanical contributions of the Lewis and Clark expedition, it was exciting to examine the plant specimens, but it was a tedious task to search the various published accounts of the journey to extract from the mass of miscellaneous information the obsemations relating to natural history.

Now, in this book, Cutright has provided a pleasantly readable chronological history of that two year trek up the Missouri River and across the mountains to the west coast of Washington and Oregon as seen through the eyes of the naturalists that Lewis and Clark proved themselves to be. By winnowing out the information on natural history from the various documents and illuminating it with his personal observations and enthusiasm, the author has produced a book to be enjoyed by armchair travellers and professional naturalists alike.

The format of the book is pleasing, the index appears to be complete, and there is an ample bibliography. The author obviously has been painstaking in his research. For the convenience of scientists who might want to examine the collections made by Lewis and Clark, particularly to search for those that might be "types," there are interesting chapters on "The Fate of the Lewis and Clark Booty"; a
short chapter, "Summing Up"; and three appendices—Appendix A, "Plants Discovered by Lewis and Clark"; Appendix B, "Animals Discovered by Lewis and Clark"; and Appendix c, "Locations of Lewis and Clark Journals, Maps, and Related Materials."

Criticisms are relatively minor. It would have been useful to have had a plant taxonomist scrutinize Appendix A before publication. There are a few points of nomenclature that could have been corrected; for example, the scientific name of the Osage Orange now is Maclura pomifera (Raf.) Sehneid. rather than Maclura aurantiaca Nutt. In a book of this sort one always wishes there were more illustrations. A general map of the region traversed should have been included for the benefit of readers not familiar with that part of the world.
div.byline: Smithsonian Institution, Washington, D. C. Velva E. Rudd

div.head: Dwight L. Moody: American Evangelist, 1837–1899. By James F. Findlay, Jr. Foreword by Martin E. Marty. (Chicago: The University of Chicago Press, 1969. Pp. ix, 440. Notes, illustrations, note on sources, index. $10.00.)
div.p: Dwight L. Moody, heir of Charles G. Finney and spiritual forefather of Billy Graham, was a force to be reckoned with in late nineteenth century Protestantism and, indeed, in American society as a whole. Findlay's book, the outgrowth of a Northwestern University doctoral dissertation, gives us a sober, amply documented, and very clearly written account of the evangelist's personality and public career. As such it illuminates not only the life of one religious leader, but the ethos of American society during the Gilded Age.

Findlay argues that any adequate essay about Moody must accomplish three objectives. To begin with, Moody must be seen in the "inner" context of nineteenth century evangelical Protestantism. The frame of reference which guided his decisions must be exposed and analyzed. Second, Moody's responses to the "outer" society of Gilded Age America—a society marked by a population shift to the cities and by the domination of vast business interests—must be considered. Finally, some feeling for the evangelist's personality should strike the reader. While the distinction between "inner" and "outer" history— brought to the fore by H. Richard Niebuhr in such works as The Meaning of Revelation and The Kingdom of God in America—is, in the judgment of this reviewer, not especially helpful, nevertheless on all points Findlay has clearly accomplished what he set out to do.

Poorly educated, Moody spent the first years of his life in the shoe business before entering full time work for the Chicago YMCA
in 1860. Around 1870 his career suffered two setbacks. The buildings housing a school and church he had founded were destroyed in the Chicago fire; and, concurrently, he went through a period of severe depression. He had felt a kind of conversion during the two years he spent in Boston, but in the winter of 1871 he experienced a "second conversion." Thus, driven by circumstances and pulled by experience, Moody embarked on his career as a professional evangelist. Throughout the 1870s he conducted a series of incredibly successful revivals both in Great Britain and the United States.

At these revivals Moody preached a rather undogmatic but vaguely traditional theology which could be very reassuring to people challenged by the horrors and opportunities of urban existence. Backed to the hilt by prominent businessmen—his pay always came in the form of honoraria—Moody's revivals were dignified affairs, free from turmoil. Although designed to appeal to unchurched masses, they, in fact, were largely attended by the middle class—which viewed Moody as one of its own. The businesslike style of the revivals, combined with the established appearance and familiar theology of the evangelist, enabled the meetings to serve as an aid to the small town American in his "acculturation to urban life" (p. 289).

The fever of enthusiasm could not be continued indefinitely, and late in his career Moody had to adopt new evangelistic techniques (smaller, more intimate meetings) and establish new institutions (the Northfield schools, what is now called the Moody Bible Institute) in order to try to maintain momentum.

Moody was unappreciative of the developing social gospel response to urban problems and obscurantistic towards developments in Biblical studies. He found it easier to give up an enterprise and start over than to work for institutional change. In all this he serves as an epitome of American Protestantism. Perhaps his energy, lack of dogmatism, modesty, and pervasive good intentions are only slightly less typical. In any event, scholars are in Findlay's debt for calling him, again, to our attention.
div.byline: Indiana University, Bloomington David H. Smith

div.head: From Hayes to McKinley: National Party Politics, 1877-1896. By H. Wayne Morgan. (Syracuse: Syracuse University Press, 1969. Pp. x, 618. Illustrations, bibliographical note, notes to chapters, index. $12.95.)
div.p:
Those interested in political history and political personalities in the two decades from the Compromise of 1877 to the election of 1896 are greatly indebted to H. Wayne Morgan, professor of history at the
University of Texas, for this admirable survey of that important period. The author has accomplished what the title implies he intended—to produce a book about national party politics. One ought not, therefore, to criticize him for neglecting diplomatic, economic, or constitutional history, as he does, or for failing to elaborate upon local or sectional issues.

This is a long book, but it is well written and holds the reader's attention. Even though the story in general is familiar, there are just enough new viewpoints and fresh materials to keep one alert and fascinated. Organized chronologically, the twelve chapters are grouped into three parts with sections of pertinent photographs at the end of each part. The first five chapters deal with the Hayes administration, the election of 1880, the James A. Garfield-Chester A. Arthur era, and the notorious presidential campaign of 1884. Part two devotes four chapters to Grover Cleveland's first term and to the administration of Benjamin Harrison, and the third part reviews the trials and tribulations of the second Cleveland administration and the election of 1896.

Morgan presents the view that the differences between the Democratic and Republican parties were sharp and significant in the era discussed. He holds that the Republicans spoke for an emerging businessman-skilled labor-prosperous farmer coalition and believed in stronger national government whereas the Democrats clung to Jef-fersonian ideals of local rule and a limited federal government and never understood the changes that were coming in the United States after the Civil War.

Among the best sections of the book are the numerous, skillfully written, biographical sketches of leading political figures and the analyses of the Cabinets formed by each of the Presidents. If there is a "hero," it is James G. Blaine, "easily the GOP's most commanding public figure" (p. 22), "a convivial, popular, and usually moderate man" (p. 66), "the most compelling figure of the day" (p. 67), who "typified the ‘American’ aspect of every issue of his time" (p. 68).

Another personality to emerge in a most favorable light is William McKinley (about whom Morgan has previously written a biography). "A small-town man with considerable sophistication, and a political success who never let power or fame turn his head," McKinley "typified the popular self-made man wishing to keep the system open for others" (p. 483); and "in his own time, he was a liberal Republican, as many followers who later became reformers readily attested" (p. 485).

Although the author rather obviously regards the Democratic party of the late nineteenth century, and such men as Samuel J. Tilden and Cleveland in particular, with something less than enthusiasm, his
treatment of controversial issues and personalities is moderate and judicious.
From Hayes to McKinley is a first rate work and deserves a wide readership.
div.byline: Davis and Elkins College, Elkins, W. Va. Thomas Richard Ross

div.head: Pacifism in the United States: From the Colonial Era to the First World War. By Peter Brock. (Princeton: Princeton University Press, 1968. Pp. xii, 1005, Notes, bibliography, index. $18.50.)
div.p: Of the growing number of books published in recent years on antiwar sentiment in America, Peter Brock's Pacifism in the United States is one of the most impressive. The study in no way attempts to trace the general history of the peace movement up to the First World War. Instead Brock's major aim is "to tell the story of the religious groups whose members refused military service on the basis of their objection to war, and of that section of the organized peace movement which … repudiated all war" (p. vii).

Admitting that the intellectual origins of American sectarian pacifism can be found in Europe, Brock argues convincingly that the American experience "subtly and gradually produced alterations in both the expression and organization" of the nonviolent testimony in the United States (p. 18). These changes can particularly be seen in the peace witness of the Society of Friends (to which Brock devotes most of his attention in the first third of the book). British Quakers had little contact with the uses and practices of political power; but in America, and especially in Pennsylvania, Quakers did gain power and were forced to harmonize their nonviolent commitment with their political responsibilities throughout the colonial period. Although this theme is not original, Brock's study does succeed in clearly defining the limits of American sectarian pacifism better than most previous accounts. He ably clarifies the variety of positions taken and the often ambivalent responses of such groups as the Society of Friends, the Mennonites, the Brethren, and the Moravians. The issue faced by pacifists was not merely the question of military service, but also the more complex and difficult problems involved in the payment of fines for refusing to serve, the payment of taxes for military purposes, and the participation in governmental processes when the government remained committed to the use of force and violence.

In dealing with the period between the Revolution and the Civil War, Brock not only continues his analysis of sectarian pacifism, but
also studies in depth the pacifistic aspects of the nonsectarian peace movement. Here he goes over the familiar ground so ably covered by Merle Curti in his pioneering study The American Peace Crusade. Brock is less interested than was Curti in the institutional aspects of the peace movement. His main focus is on the ideas, arguments, and experiences of those Americans adhering to the principles of absolute pacifism. His major contribution, however, is not that he offers any new or startling interpretation, but rather that he introduces a vast amount of new material.

Brock's meticulous research and his ability to organize effectively the data he has uncovered make his study extremely valuable to historians of reform and religion. His style is clear and readable although this reviewer would have preferred that he discuss his research problems in footnotes rather than in the text. The major weaknesses of the study tend to be ones of omission rather than commission. His analysis of the arguments and ideas of nonsectarian pacifists is profound, but he fails to deal with these individuals on a group level and neglects to ask if they shared any common traits that might help explain their predilection for nonviolence. Brock is certainly correct in arguing that pacifism was rooted in Christian ideology and the New Testament, but whereas he demonstrates that group pressure within religious denominations espousing pacifism often forced conformity to the nonviolent principle, he sheds little light on the motivation of American nonsectarian pacifists.

It is in dealing with the post-Civil War period that Brock's study suffers most. His treatment of the period from 1865 to 1914 is shoddy and occupies only a minor portion of his lengthy book. He justifies this imbalance by claiming that little new developed in the testimony of American pacifists and that it was not until the First World War that the nonviolent aspects of the peace movement shifted direction significantly. Yet the period between the Civil War and the First World War saw the rise of a more militant American nationalism, a war with Spain, and the growth of the United States as a world power. A deeper analysis into the reaction of American pacifists to these events would have strengthened his study considerably.

These criticisms, however, should not obscure the fact that Pacifism in the United States is an extremely important and worthwhile study and will no doubt be very well received by most scholars. Unfortunately its length, concentration on detail, and price will probably make it less appealing to the general reader.
div.byline: The University of North Carolina, Charlotte Harold Josephson

div.head: Prairie Farmer and WLS: The Burridge D. Butler Years. By James F. Evans. (Urbana: University of Illinois Press, 1969. Pp. 329. Notes, illustrations, tables, bibliography, index. $8.50.)
div.p: James F. Evans, head of the teaching division of the Office of Agricultural Communications at the University of Illinois, has succeeded admirably in weaving together both a biography of Burridge D. Butler and a detailed analysis of two important mass media organizations which he came to control early in the twentieth century—the Prairie Farmer newspaper and Chicago's WLS radio station. Evans meticulously covers the details of Butler's career showing the growth and influence of Prairie Farmer from 1909 to 1939, when circulation under Butler's leadership increased from 30,000 to more than 300,000. The author presents ample evidence to document Butler's organizational skill as Prairie Farmer emerged as one of the leading midwestern farm newspapers.

Clifford V. Gregory, Butler's editor-in-chief, helped him launch a number of farm programs, e.g., the American Farm Bureau Federation, leadership in forming the farm block in the Midwest, cooperative sales and marketing, and New Deal farm policies in the late 1920s and the successive New Deal years. Evans' account of these campaigns is well stated, and he clearly shows that Butler's "crusading spirit" set him apart as an important champion of the farm community.

Butler referred paternalistically to his loyal supporters as his "Midwest family." However, this paternalism was turned into positive action, for he helped support numerous state fairs, hosted several national barn dances, financed the Boy Scouts, Girl Scouts, farm youth groups, Blackburn College, and many other worthy civic organizations.

The author's comments on WLS, the voice of the midwestern farm community, make up the most lively section of his narrative. Butler's association and ownership of WLS spanned the years 1924 to his death in 1948, shortly after his eightieth birthday. WLS broadcasters from Chicago exerted a wide influence and established programs designed to appeal to the farm community. Evans discusses the WLS stars, Red Foley, Pat Buttram, Fibber McGee and Molly, Amos and Andy, Homer and Jethro, Gene Autry, and George Gobel, many of whom became nationally recognized radio personalities.

Evans seems to fall short of his mark in one area—the analysis of Butler's personality. The author contends that the "dissimilar personalities" of Butler's parents "help explain the fluidity of his own" (p. 12). Neither the examples nor the arguments Evans offers are convincing when he claims Butler is a highly sensitive man. In fact, the examples would indicate just the opposite. Butler comes off as a brash man, whose anti-Semitism, feelings of inadequacy, schizophrenic
seizures, arrogant attitudes, and directed tactics of intimidation toward his employees indicate his rigidity, rather than his sensitivity.

The author's research is conscientious, and his book offers the reader a fresh perspective on the midwestern farm community from 1910 to 1960 through the active life of Butler. In short, Evans has written an exciting narrative account to fill an important chapter in agricultural communications history.
div.byline: Miami University, Oxford, O. Philip Morehouse McGarr

div.head: Mark Twain & the Bible. By Allison Ensor. (Lexington: University of Kentucky Press, 1969. Pp. 130. Notes, index. $4.75.)
div.p: This book illustrates Dixon Wecter's comment that Mark Twain, in a protracted encounter with the Bible, had "the will to disbelieve, but also a lifelong fascination with the mythology …" (p. 4). Fascination appears in many Twainian allusions to Biblical scenes and characters, his feeling of kinship with Adam and the Prodigal Son, and his fondness for scriptural quotations, often misquoted. Ensor cites numerous examples, besides statistics gleaned from Twain's writing: 295 references to Genesis, 133 to Matthew, 44 to Christ, 34 to Noah, and so on.

Disbelief motivates attacks upon the sacred truths of fundamentalists, who practice, Twain said, "that kind of so-called housekeeping where they have six Bibles and no corkscrew" (p. 78). From disparagement of the Holy Land in Innocents Abroad to savage assaults upon the Bible in Letters From the Earth and elsewhere, occasional reverence is overmatched by irreverence, disgust with hypocritical piety, contempt for a petty, vindictive God who massacred the innocent and invented hell. A year before his death Twain concluded that the Bible "has noble poetry in it; and some clever fables; and some blood-drenched history; and some good morals; and a wealth of obscenity; and upwards of a thousand lies" (p. 73). The long confrontation offers the familiar spectacle of a rebellious Twain, scornful of genteel conventions, vying with the conformist courting respectability.

Ensor hews to the line with a zeal commendable, if solemn; but he might have ranged further to test his contention that Twain, overstressing biblical shortcomings, was "at the same time blind to its virtues" (p. 101). An unexplored topic is his appreciation of the sound and rhythm of biblical language. A seasoned public speaker sensitive to modulation and pace, he was observant of pulpit mannerisms, noting that clergymen often destroyed the stately beauty of the Lord's Prayer by rushing through it, as if convinced that the faster they said it the sooner it would be answered. The reminiscences of Charles
Warren Stoddard tell of Twain's reading aloud from Isaiah and the Book of Ruth in a minor tone powerful and moving. These matters invite consideration.

Jim's engaging remarks about King Sollermun in Huckleberry Finn, the entertaining discussion of the Mormon Bible in Roughing It, and Captain Stormfield—all merit attention. Surely deserving notice is "The Man That Corrupted Hadleyburg" for its sardonic ridicule of the unwise plea, "Lead us not into temptation."

Undoubtedly, as Ensor maintains, Twain was not a systematic Bible student, and his strong pronouncements echo those of Tom Paine and Robert Ingersoll. More questionable is the implication that nowadays Twain's old-fashioned Bible baiting is outmoded. Perhaps, yet his flair for vivid statement still makes lively reading and possibly, in certain quarters, continues to disturb. Hellfire no longer sizzles with its former heat, and fundamentalism is not obtrusive, but neither may be extinct. That Letters From the Earth (1962) shocked some readers suggests that rough treatment of Holy Writ scarifies contemporary believers unenlightened by the higher criticism

Carping aside, Mark Twain & the Bible is a scholarly exposition of the shifting emotions, gentle and explosive, of a paradoxical genius who could neither take the Bible nor let it alone. Like that provocative Book, which fascinated him, he too fascinates, confounding critics and frustrating classifiers.

div.head: My Life with History: An Autobiography. By John D. Hicks. (Lincoln: University of Nebraska Press, 1968. Pp. ix, 366. Notes, index. $5.95.)
div.p: Here is a charming book written by an historian whose active academic career has spanned the last half century. This autobiography of John D. Hicks also illuminates the shifting life and customs of American society since the turn of the century. Since 1890, the year Hicks was born in Missouri, population in the United States has increased threefold, and the passing decades have seen the growing dominance of an urban America. Quite clearly Professor Hicks feels that the story of his own life illustrates the comment of Richard Hofstader that "The United States was born in the country and has moved to the city" (p. viii). He believes that Americans need to recall and know their rural past in order to understand their urban present.

The son of a Methodist preacher, Hicks grew up in a number of parsonages in several small towns in Missouri. Shortly after his
graduation from high school the family moved west to Wyoming, where Don Hicks (as he was then called) worked briefly as a sheepherder before spending two years as a country schoolteacher. The author took his savings and entered Northwestern University where he received a B.A. degree in 1913 and a Master's degree the following year. Contrary to family expectations, the young graduate did not follow in his father's footsteps, but instead turned to the University of Wisconsin. There in two busy years he finished a Ph.D. under the guidance of Frederick L. Paxson and Carl Russell Fish.

Hicks started his teaching career at Hamline University, and after a year's stay at the North Carolina College for Women at Greensboro, moved on to the University of Nebraska in 1923. It was at Nebraska that he wrote The Populist Revolt and became in turn department chairman and dean of his college In his position as dean he soon learned what he viewed as the first rule of good college administration: "Under no circumstances should a president, or a chancellor, or a provost, or a dean appear to have any ideas" (p. 150). Later he moved on to the University of Wisconsin and after a decade in Madison was named Morrison Professor of History at the University of California, Berkeley. During his years in Madison he wrote the two popular college history texts, The Federal Union and The American Nation, volumes that have been widely used in hundreds of survey courses.

My Life with History provides a broad glimpse of a long departed rural America plus an inside view of the historical profession and the world of academia. Hicks has filled his volume with fascinating detail and incident, traits which earlier made his lectures popular with the hundreds of undergraduate and graduate students that he knew in his long teaching career. Any reader, middle aged or older, who knows middlewestern America will find this book a delight. This should be especially true for those readers, young or old, who are teachers of American history.
div.byline: Purdue University, Lafayette John F. Stover

div.head: A Search for Stability: United States Diplomacy Toward Nicaragua, 1925–1933. By William Kamman. (Notre Dame: University of Notre Dame Press, 1968. Pp. xiii, 263. Notes, bibliographical essay, index. $7.95.)
div.p: The first United States military intervention in Nicaragua lasted from 1912 to 1925. The second intervention, which began with the return of United States forces in 1926 and continued until 1933, is the subject of Kamman's study.

Several reasons motivated the second United States intervention: concern with the area's strategic importance, a fear of "communist" influences believed to emanate from Mexico, and a genuine desire for stability and democracy. President Woodrow Wilson's policy of not recognizing governments that came to power by unconstitutional means—that is, by revolution—was supposed to encourage democracy. Instead, it confronted the United States with a dilemma; either acquiesce in lengthy dictatorial governments or intervene militarily. The incumbents in Nicaragua—Liberal or Conservative—almost never permitted the outs to fake office by electoral means; only revolution was effective.

During the second intervention, the United States replaced Conservative President Emiliano Chamorro, who had achieved his office by revolt, with Conservative Adolfo Diaz. It then defended Diaz against a serious Liberal revolt. The United States gradually increased its military forces in the country until, inexorably, they were drawn into war with Liberal guerrillas led by Augusto Sandino. While holding him at bay, the United States supervised free elections and created a "non-political" national guard to continue the work of the marines. The withdrawal of the marines in 1933 left Sandino still on the field. He was killed shortly afterwards on orders of Anastasio Somoza, who proceeded to use the guard as the basis for a dictatorship that still endures.

Kamman shows the intervention was not costly in lives nor money, nor even anti-United States feeling in Nicaragua. Its real cost was the strengthening of our imperialist image in Latin America. The intervention was a sorry experience for United States policy makers, including such an able and skilled man as Henry Stimson, because it failed to promote a permanent solution of Nicaragua's problems. Kamman's expressed hope that current policy makers will learn from his study is certainly appropriate in this day of Castroite guerrillas. Sandino's defiance of the marines was the beginning of the legend in the Caribbean that guerrillas can always defeat regular forces.

Kamman's detailed monograph is based upon United States official records and assorted personal papers. The style is sometimes heavy, and the reader would benefit from a clearer explanation of Nicaraguan politics, which is essentially based on the extended-family. It is, however, a solid, useful study, for the author successfully leads the reader through the intricate and myriad details of day-to-day diplomacy.

div.head: Review Notices
div.p: A Sketchbook of Indiana History. By Arville L. Funk. (Rochester, Ind.: Christian Book Press, 1969. Pp. 223. Illustrations, maps, notes, appendix. $4.75.) The approximately forty sketches which appear in this volume range from those concerning Little Turtle, Jacob Wetzel, James Oliver, Isaac McCoy, Benjamin Harrison, and Harvey W. Wiley to others regarding the Moundbuilders, Whitewater Canal, Corydon and Harrison County, New Harmony, and Conner Prairie Museum. According to the author they originally appeared in such publications as Indiana Magazine of History, Outdoor Indiana, Indiana History Bulletin, and Teaching Indiana History. Unfortunately, however, the author neglects to indicate the particular source for each article. These popular sketches are quite suitable for use by students and teachers of Indiana history at either the junior or senior high level, but they can also be read with interest and profit by students and adults generally. (Orders for this volume should be sent to ALFCO Publications, P.O. Box 66, Corydon, Indiana 47112.)

Reminiscences of Levi Coffin, the Reputed President of the Underground Railroad. Reprints of Economic Classics. (New York: Augustus M. Kelley, 1968. Pp. viii, 712. Illustrations. $15.00.) Coffin's Reminiscences, a classic of the antislavery literature of the nineteenth century, merits careful study by persons seeking to understand the role and status of the Negro in American life. Although the reminiscences relate varied aspects of Coffin's eventful life, their central concern is the plight of blacks—both slave and free—preceding, during, and immediately following the Civil War. In an engaging and vivid manner, this Quaker native of North Carolina gives impressive and convincing evidence of Negro discontent with slavery and a desire for freedom. While resident of Wayne County, Indiana, and Cincinnati, Ohio, Coffin aided literally hundreds of Negroes, slave and free alike, to escape the clutches of slavery. This benevolent Quaker gentleman also fought slavery on the economic front, even moving to Cincinnati for a period to promote the consumption of goods produced by free labor in an effort to weaken slavery by decreasing the market for items largely or at least significantly dependent upon slave labor for their production. Coffin's views, however modest they may now seem to some, were regarded as extreme and inappropriate by most of his contemporaries in eastern Indiana and Cincinnati. As Coffin himself indicates now and then, even many of his fellow Quakers considered him too militant and too aggressve in his efforts on behalf of blacks.

A 30–Year History of the Indiana Federation of Clubs. By Johnnie Rutland Smith. (Indiana Federation of Clubs, 1969. Pp. 52. Illustrations, appendix. Pamphlet.) Mrs. Smith, former president of the Indiana Federation of Clubs offers highlights of the history of the federation and its affiliated local clubs for the three decades, 1938-1968. Brief sketches covering the periods served by federation presidents are given; considerable is indicated of the topics and goals emphasized by the federation; and a roster is offered of the presidents of the thirteen districts. The Indiana Federation of Clubs has made important and continuing contributions to developments within Indiana. For instance, the federation has contributed significantly to an enlarged emphasis upon conservation, fine arts, and the study of Indiana history. Incidentally, those individuals who think the Indiana Federation of Clubs has always been exclusively for women are reminded that "men have been members and in 1898 the organization had a man, Prof. John Wisely, Terre Haute, as president" (p. 5).

The Michigan State Capitol. A John M. Munson History Fund Publication. (Lansing: Michigan Historical Commission, 1969. Illustrations, notes. Pp. 39. Pamphlet.) This illustrated, historical sketch describes buildings which have served as Michigan's capitol from territorial days to the present. Made possible by the John M. Munson Michigan History Fund, it merits wide use by students, public officials, and adults generally. A similar publication is needed regarding buildings which have been used as Indiana's capitol—from territorial days at Vincennes, through the transition period at Corydon, and including the buildings at Indianapolis which have served as the state capitol.

The Indiana Social Studies Quarterly. Edited by Richard Wires. Vol. XXI, No. 3. (Muncie: Ball State University and the Indiana Council for the Social Studies, Winter, 1968-1969. Pp. 104. Magazine.) This review and evaluation of important topics and personalities associated with the peace conference at the conclusion of World War I covers a wide range of material. Among the ten essays are two which consider World War I and the Versailles Conference as treated in high school texts; another offers a bibliographical essay concerning books useful as references in instruction at the secondary level regarding World War I and the ensuing peace settlement. This volume should be of particular value to high school teachers of American history.
